business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer the minister to comments of the head of ATSIC, Mr Gatjil Djerrkura, who said recently:

question.para: Despite the gains in indigenous education in the past three decades, indigenous students lag behind other Australians by almost any measure of participation or attainment.

Why then is the government proceeding with changes to Abstudy, changes which will, one, result in more than $18 million being cut from the Abstudy budget and, two, significantly disadvantage more than 14,000 indigenous students in tertiary education?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Bolkus for the question because Abstudy is a very serious issue. But, unfortunately, the content of Senator Bolkus's question is incorrect. The ATSIC report contains a number of incorrect assumptions and has, in many cases, extrapolated too much from insufficient data. The breakdown of affected populations is inaccurate and the calculation of financial gain or loss resulting from the changes for certain student population groups is not correct.

answer.para: Conclusions about financial impact—for example, that the Abstudy budget could be reduced in 2000 by as much as $18.1 million—are flawed largely because of the premise that all students currently enrolled in courses will continue into 2000 and a significant overestimation of the number of pensioner education supplement beneficiaries. Over 80 per cent of Abstudy beneficiaries should experience no or minimal change—and by that I mean less than 7c a week—to Abstudy benefits.

There are changes to Abstudy for 2000 to align benefits payable to indigenous students with those payments to non-indigenous students, unless the disadvantage addressed by the benefit is unique to or disproportionately concentrated upon indigenous students. Abstudy supplementary benefits have been retained. Abstudy students will have their pensioner education allowance aligned with those payable to non-indigenous students. Of those tertiary students who will experience a decrease in the Abstudy living allowance, up to 60 per cent may gain access for the first time to mainstream related entitlements such as rent assistance, remote area allowance and pharmaceutical allowance.

In recognition of their particular circumstances, tertiary Abstudy students of 21 years or older receive a higher rate of living allowance than Austudy recipients, can access mainstream related benefits which Austudy students cannot and retain access to supplementary Abstudy benefits which address specific advantages.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the ATSIC study was actually conducted by independent organisations, unlike the minister's answer. Minister, why is the government proceeding with these socially irresponsible cuts to an area which, on any consideration, really needs extra assistance rather than reduced assistance?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I do not think that Senator Bolkus listened to my answer. In the answer I gave, I said that the assumptions that he made in his question, and which were also made in the Abstudy paper, were based on false premises. I am happy to provide those. I think Senator Bolkus should await further developments.
—I ask the minister to table the document from which he was reading.

—My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Will the minister inform the Senate of what further measures the government is proposing to generate real jobs growth and to tackle the legacy of Labor's unacceptably high level of unemployment? Also, is the minister aware of any alternative policy proposals, and what would be the impact if these proposals were implemented?
—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Can I ask you if the second part of Senator Tchen's question is in order in your view, given previous rulings you have made about these sorts of matters?

—Madam President, I do not know whether there is any need to pursue this point. I cannot believe Senator Faulkner is serious. It is a longstanding practice in this chamber to invite government ministers to comment on alternative approaches and to explore whether they might be suitable for adoption as government policy. The whole nature of the exercise in canvassing these issues is to invite the minister to state the government's approach to a range of issues. Clearly, if there are alternatives around in the marketplace, they ought to be properly examined and commented upon.
—Order! It is not appropriate to ask about Labor Party policies and identified policies in that fashion, but it is possible to ask to identify any other proposals.
—On the point of order, Madam President: does that mean you are ruling out the second part of the question?
—I am not ruling out the second part of the question as I heard it, but I shall check the precise wording of it later, and I shall certainly listen to the minister's answer. I call Senator Alston.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Certainly we regard the level of unemployment in this country as still being too high, but it is trending in the right direction. It is down to 7.1 per cent—the lowest it has been since 1990, which was about the time when Mr Beazley was the minister for unemployment. Quite clearly, we are determined to go further and faster if we possibly can. We certainly think that strong economic growth is a prerequisite to improving the employment outlook, and that is why the Ralph initiatives, along with taxation reform, are very much designed to assist small business and to promote employment opportunities wherever possible.

answer.para: The highly successful Work for the Dole Program, which we are now improving and expanding upon, is yet another indication of the sensible approach being taken by the government to tackling these issues. There is no point in having people sitting on the sidelines wishing that they had jobs but not having the skills or the opportunities to pursue them. That is why doubling places for the Work for the Dole Program by 2001 and making it available to year 12 school leavers still unemployed after three months and to those aged 25 to 34 years still unemployed after 12 months or more is again a very positive initiative. It is very much welcomed by those who are out of work. That is what mutual obligation is all about. They understand that it is very much in their own interests not just to put their hands out and get a welfare payment but to have the opportunity to at least practise. If you are not able to get the full-time job that you are looking for, you have the opportunity in on-the-job training programs to hone the skills that will be required down the track.

Apprenticeships and traineeships were just run into the ground by the Labor Party, who had absolutely no interest in them, for the simple reason that the unions did not like them. We have now managed to get the numbers for those schemes up above 200,000. We are aiming for 500,000 new apprenticeships and traineeships, and we have allocated $1.6 billion over four years. Schools funding continues to increase, with $131 million for the vital job skills of literacy and numeracy. So on a whole range of fronts, we are making progress. But we need to go further and we need to accept that ongoing structural change, properly tempered, will be an important ingredient, together with sound economic management.

I was asked whether there are any alternatives in the marketplace; I have to say, tragically for the people of Australia, that there are not. We simply do not have any policy proposals being put forward by the other major party in this place. Mr Beazley, the current Leader of the Opposition, in the one seminar that he went to on unemployment—he wandered down to RMIT for about a five minute burst—came out saying that the options canvassed had no formal status. So clearly there is not any alternative in the whole area of unemployment. But he did say that he would be launching a more detailed policy discussion paper in September. Today is the 28th, so we have not got long to go.

talk.start.para: —You want our policies again, Richard?

—You have put the media on red alert, have you? We are going to get something released in the next day or two? Instead of announcing Gareth Evans's resignation, you could go down to the Press Club and make a substantial policy statement. But, of course we know that that is not going to happen. Presumably all we will get is the Cheryl Kernot defence: `I am overworked and under-resourced and I am basically too lazy to do anything about it until we get much closer to the next election.'

answer.para: In talking to the Evatt Foundation only a couple of weeks ago, what did we hear: `Labor must avoid rushing into releasing policy.' That is one thing they have delivered on in spades; they have made it perfectly obvious that they are basically going to sit back and do nothing for the next couple of years and hope that the low cost, low risk alternative will somehow get them there—and it will not. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Can the minister explain why the daily media briefings by Colonel Lewis at the Australian Defence Headquarters in Russell on the East Timor deployment were abruptly cancelled last Thursday? Were these important information sessions for the media and the Australian public cancelled because the Canberra based media were getting information directly from Defence on issues such as troop rotation difficulties, shortages of specialist staff and reserve recruitment problems? Wasn't this information proving to be severely embarrassing to the Minister for Defence, Mr Moore, by contradicting his statements on these issues and making him look just plain foolish? Who ordered the cancellation of these briefings, and what role did the minister play in the cancellation of the briefings?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I have no brief on this matter from the Minister for Defence. I would have thought that the Australian people would have had a great deal of information on the deployment to East Timor of the INTERFET force. Night after night, day after day, morning after morning, evening after evening, we have had updates on the work of the force. I do not know if there is any change in the briefing arrangements; I will certainly see whether there is any further information I can get for the senator.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would appreciate the minister taking that question on notice and providing an urgent answer to the Senate. I ask as a supplementary question: is it not the fact that there is a clear and a continuing need for accurate information about the Timor deployment to be provided to the Australian people using as many means as possible, including the Canberra press gallery? Given the Minister for Defence's own incapacity to provide accurate and detailed information on the East Timor deployment, will the minister reconsider his decision to cancel these important briefings?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I have no way of knowing at this point as to whether the minister did or did not have anything to do with any change in the briefing arrangements. I have said to you that I will get what information I can for you. I have also said that there is a great deal of information flowing, so quite clearly there is not a clampdown on information coming from the force. I think the allegations made by Senator Faulkner are not justified.

answer.para: I think that Australians are very proud of what their people are doing. They are very proud of the fact that we are leading a regional force. We are delighted at the ability that they have had already to secure airfields and also to make so much of Dili safe for East Timorese to walk around in. I am not accepting the allegations made by Senator Faulkner, because I do not know whether they are correct, but I would point out that sometimes when people are on operations some details cannot be made available to the media, for the protection of our own forces. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, Senator Ian Macdonald.
—The popular senator.

—The popular senator, indeed. Will the minister outline to the Senate the particular benefits to small businesses and job creation in regional Australia of the government's major tax reform announcements? How has the government consulted to deliver these outcomes?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator Lightfoot again raises a very important question for the government, for the Liberal and National parties—that is, the people of regional Australia and how the government can assist them in adding to the good things that have come out of regional Australia. The tax package that Senator Lightfoot speaks about is yet another of the government's initiatives in this particular area. It follows on a number of other initiatives that we think have been good news for country Australia. We still have a long way to go, but we have started on it.

answer.para: Senator Lightfoot asked me how we have consulted to deliver these outcomes. You do that by going out and listening to the people of regional Australia. I and my colleagues do that regularly—Mr Anderson, as the senior minister, Senator Boswell, Senator Troeth. Ministers in this area go out and listen to people. I can only urge the Labor Party to do the same. Regrettably, their spokesman, Ms Kernot, seems to be too busy to get out and listen to what regional Australians are saying. She says she is too busy looking after her marginal seat. She says she is looking after aviation matters. Former Senator Graham Richardson said, `If Ms Kernot is looking after aviation matters, it is the best kept secret in town.' I would have thought that Senator Woodley was the opposition spokesman on aviation. At least he asks some questions.

But Madam Kernot—I do apologise for that, Madam President. Fancy confusing you with Ms Kernot! You are visible, you do great work in Canberra; Ms Kernot has simply disappeared from the screen. She certainly has not been out in regional Australia. I know that there are many Labor senators from Western Australia, from the Northern Territory, from North Queensland, who have asked Ms Kernot to come up and speak to them and she has not gone there. When was she last in the Northern Territory? When was she last in regional Australia? She blew into Rockhampton. She would not even know where it is. She thinks she is too busy looking after a marginal electorate.

I have to say that Mr Anderson, the senior minister, is in a very marginal electorate but he seems to manage to get out and consult. We all do. I have driven throughout western Queensland, stopping at every little town and speaking to people. But you do not see Ms Kernot. You might remember that when Senator Faulkner immortalised the coffee pot in getting Ms Kernot to rat on the Democrats and join the Labor Party there were great things in store for Ms Kernot, but she has simply disappeared from the scene.
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much noise. We are waiting for some silence in the chamber so that we can proceed with question time. There are far too many senators interjecting.

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator Woodley was right when he let the cat out of the bag. When Ms Kernot was Leader of the Democrats she said, `Don't go near the bush. There aren't votes for us there.' I think she is following that philosophy now. When asked why she does not go there, do you know what she does? She blames her colleague, Lindsay Tanner. She says it is all his fault that they do not have a regional policy. Then when she was pressed on it she spent three-quarters of her interview with Carolyn Tucker on ABC this morning blaming the media for the fact that she has not got out into regional Australia and consulted.

answer.para: This is not good enough for regional Australia. The Labor Party has not got much to contribute. As well as Mr Anderson, me, Senator Boswell, Senator Troeth and other ministers going out into the field, we would like the opposition to show some interest, to get out there. We do plead with Ms Kernot that, if she cannot handle the job, if it is too big a job for her, she should resign and let someone else do it. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: House Building Prices

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware of the phenomenon in the housing industry, as reported by the National Architect's Advisory Centre, Archicentre, that house building prices are being pushed up by as much as 20 per cent in anticipation of a GST? How widespread is this problem? Is Archicentre correct in saying it is happening in `most parts of Australia'?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —One thing this government has done is make housing very affordable for Australians. I remind the Senate that under the Labor government, home mortgage rates in some areas went as high as 17 per cent and heading north, whereas under this government we have brought housing rates way, way down to around 6.5 per cent, and some can even strike a lower rate. We have been able to make housing far more affordable for the majority of Australians.

answer.para: I am aware that some people are saying that there is a boom in the housing area. Of course, this means that more Australians are buying houses, which is a good thing. More Australians can presumably afford to buy housing, which is a good thing. Australians are able to make that choice because we are in a situation where unemployment levels have come down and real incomes are rising. As I said, I am aware that in some areas there is a boom in housing. It shows that there is strong demand.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. In response to what I think was a pretty specific question from Senator Gibbs—asking about the report of the National Architect's Advisory Centre that house building prices are going up by as much as 20 per cent, how widespread that is and whether the centre was correct in saying that this was happening in most parts of Australia—Senator Kemp is only able to tell us at this stage that there is a boom in housing in Australia. This was a pretty specific question. Even Senator Kemp, I would have thought, might be able to have a crack at answering it, and I wonder whether you can direct him to do so.

—Senator Faulkner, the answer is relevant to the question that was asked. It may not be the answer you are wishing to hear, but I do not believe that you could say that the minister is not dealing with the matters raised by the question. I call Senator Kemp.

—Thank you, Madam President. That ruling is completely correct. I was asked about housing prices. I was asked why people were buying houses. I said that one of the reasons is that we have made housing more affordable. If Senator Faulkner does not—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. It is quite clear, Madam President, that obviously Senator Kemp did not understand the question. He has just reported to us that he was asked why people are buying houses. He was in fact asked about house building prices being pushed up 20 per cent and how widespread the problem is. He obviously did not hear the question, or if he did hear it he did not understand it. I ask you again to direct him to answer it.
—Senator, there is no point of order. I call Senator Kemp.

—Thank you, Madam President. Senator Faulkner is refusing to listen to the answer. If he had done so he would have understood that the question is being answered in great detail. Housing prices reflect—as, indeed, many prices do—supply and demand conditions. Clearly, what we are seeing in some areas is very strong demand for housing. I am explaining to the Senate why that could be occurring. I am proposing that there could be a number of reasons which are causing a demand for housing. One is the affordability of housing. Another is the fact that we have been able to bring interest rates down. Another factor is that this government has been able to preside over real wages rising. Another factor is that this government is managing to engender confidence in the community, which is a very big plus.

answer.para: There may well be some people who are looking forward to 1 July next year and very substantial tax cuts. I would point out that we are about to deliver the largest tax cuts in Australian history. This will be on 1 July. Senator Gibbs, that would be another reason why we are seeing very strong consumer confidence in this economy. The fact of the matter is that Australia has a well managed economy. Certainly, with the way this economy has been managed—it is the envy of many countries around the world—it is not surprising that many people are showing a lot of confidence and wanting to purchase houses.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, my question was about a 20 per cent increase on building costs. Could you please look into that. Also, what is the government doing to prevent this practice in the building industry to protect people who are wanting to build or renovate in advance of the around $7,000 coalition-Democrat housing cost price hike on 1 July next year? Will the GST be applied to the artificially inflated prices that are occurring now?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The senator does not seem to have realised that housing construction costs as a result of the GST may rise by about five per cent. That, of course, applies from 1 July next year. There are many reasons why housing prices rise and fall.
—It's called supply and demand.

—Yes, it is called supply and demand. I do not think I am breaking any secrets in saying that. I think that is pretty well known. Housing prices do vary, as you will be aware. What we are seeing in the economy is an underlying confidence. We are seeing a government going about a major reform agenda. People are looking forward to tax cuts. People are seeing very good figures on the employment front and good figures on the inflation front. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Hill. The minister will recall my question yesterday about Radio Australia and the current lack of reliable, independent news and information about Australia going into Indonesia. My question today is: has the minister seen reports that Indonesian media are repeating the obvious lie that Australian troops are carrying out torture and other barbaric acts in East Timor? Is the minister aware that even with the leased Taiwanese transmission facility, which he mentioned yesterday in his answer, Radio Australia is still only able to broadcast one hour of English language news and current affairs and one hour of Indonesian language news and current affairs each day into most of Indonesia, both of them time delayed? Does the minister agree that this is thoroughly inadequate if Australian attitudes and policy are to be reported and heard in a reputable and accurate way by our Indonesian neighbours? Finally, when will the government reopen Cox Peninsula to allow Australia's voice to be heard throughout Indonesia?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The point I made yesterday, which I do not think is disputed by the honourable senator, is that Cox Peninsula is not a reliable source for broadcasting into the Timor area.
—I'm not talking about Timor; I'm talking about Indonesia.
—Timor is still part of Indonesia.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are too many interjections.

—I am sorry, Madam President, but I thought that most Australians were focusing on the horrible acts that have been occurring in East Timor. In relation to East Timor, the Cox Peninsula site is unsuitable. Therefore, alternative, better suited sites are being used.

answer.para: In relation to the balance of Indonesia, as I said yesterday, another offshore site is being leased to provide the broadcasts. Senator Bourne suggests that Cox Peninsula might be a better source, but in actual fact, according to my advice, not only is it not a good source to broadcast into East Timor but also it is not suitable for broadcasting into other parts of Indonesia. Therefore, I am instructed that the mix that is now being provided for Radio Australia leads to a better outcome for the people of Indonesia, and that is what I would have thought Senator Bourne would want to hear.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would love to hear that, Senator Hill, if it were correct but unfortunately, according to my sources, it is not. The fact is that there is one hour of Radio Australia in English going into Indonesia. Do you dispute this? There is one hour of Radio Australia in Bahasa Indonesia going into most of Indonesia.
—What is your question?
—I have asked the question `Do you dispute this?' Thank you very much, Senator. I do not need your help.
—What is your question?
—That is the question!
—Order! Senator Lightfoot, cease interjecting.

—Furthermore, does the minister believe—this is all in my first question—that one hour in English and that one hour in Indonesian is adequate to get Australia's point of view across to the Indonesian people?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —One hour does not strike me as inadequate. I made the point yesterday that, from Shepparton, 23 hours were being broadcast, and I said that that sounded like a desirable outcome. If only one hour is being transmitted from the other site, I will make inquiries and find out why that is the case because I think Senator Bourne is making a good point in that regard if she is correct. In relation to Cox Peninsula, I understand that the dead zone covers an area of approximately 1,000 kilometres from the Cox Peninsula site and therefore includes some other areas of Indonesia as well as Timor.

—My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. Is the minister aware of the statements made yesterday by Professor David Flint in respect of media coverage of the republic referendum? Does the minister see any conflict between Professor Flint's role as Convener of Australians for a Constitutional Monarchy and his role as Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Authority? Given that the Australian Broadcasting Authority has relevant responsibilities under the Broadcasting Services Act and may be called upon to make determinations in respect of disputes arising from media coverage of the republic referendum, will the government ask Professor Flint to disqualify himself from ABA consideration of such issues?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I did see newspaper reports of comments attributed to Professor Flint. They essentially fell into two categories. The first, it seemed to me, was his taking issue with Lachlan Murdoch in particular about his views on the republic. I think it is legitimate for Professor Flint, particularly given his official position in representing the no case, to have views on that and to contribute to the policy debate. I did, however, notice that he was also reported as having criticised some News Ltd press coverage, although the article in which that was contained was in indirect speech, and there were no quotes to support that statement. It was also said that he said that the model to go to the 6 November referendum could jeopardise freedom of the press. I think those comments do fall into a different category, because they tend to reflect upon the motives of players in the game, be they Mr Murdoch or his newspaper group. They also constitute a comment on the behaviour of those players and the roles they play as members of the media.

answer.para: It is fair to point out that Professor Flint does not have responsibility for print. That is a matter for the Press Council. If issues were to arise in relation to radio and television, it could well be the responsibility of the Australian Broadcasting Authority, as the independent regulator of the industry, to take a position. In those circumstances, Professor Flint would need to be very careful that he did not prejudge the issues. To the extent that the comments do suggest that he has views on those matters, I think he should be very careful not to repeat them and certainly to confine his remarks to the merits of the issue, on which he does have strong views.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that considered response. I draw the minister's attention to the actual statement made by Professor Flint yesterday, where he said in respect of the proposed republic: `It would smooth the path for a power grab by the desperate man and the rogue' and `no editor or journalist could support that proposition'. Does the minister deny that this constitutes a clear conflict of interest with Professor Flint's responsibilities as Chairman of the ABA? I ask again: will the minister ask Professor Flint to disqualify himself from adjudicating on any disputes which may arise from media coverage of the republic referendum?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is entirely hypothetical to suggest that Professor Flint should disqualify himself in advance from participating.
—Why?
—Because there is no issue—
—He has made up his mind.
—Listen, clown, you would not have the faintest idea.
—Senator Alston, you are out of order speaking across the chamber to another senator in that fashion.

—However, I do not believe the remarks that Senator Bishop quoted at the start of his supplementary question fall into the category of expressing an opinion about bias or would constitute a conflict of interest. They go much more to the merits of the debate, although expressed in—
—Of course they do! You're just protecting a mate!
—Have you had enough? I have had more than enough of you.
—Senator Alston!

—Madam President, as I was saying, the comments that Senator Bishop referred to go to the merits of the debate—in other words, whether or not editors ought to be concerned and whether or not rogues or other categories of individuals might come to the fore; but that is all part of the to and fro of the controversy. I think it is legitimate for people who are participating to express themselves in strong language, but that is not in the same category as the other remarks that I spoke about. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Is the government aware that major oil companies are engaging in the practice of multi-site franchising and that this is allowing them to effectively control a potentially unlimited number of retail sites in contravention of the purposes of the sites act? What is the government going to do to protect consumers and franchise holders against excessive vertical integration by major oil companies and the reduction in competition that will occur as a result of multi-site franchising?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I am a little surprised if the honourable senator is suggesting that the oil companies are acting in contradiction to the franchise legislation. I would have thought that it would have been unwise for them to do so. I will therefore ask for clarification of that, but I do not think it would be the case. It is obviously the government's wish to ensure that the retailing of petrol is conducted in this country in a competitive environment, which can give consumers and businesses the best chance of prices that reflect real competition, and also service that reflects that competition.

answer.para: I concede that this has been an ongoing challenge for governments within this country. But the honourable senator would know of not only the role that this government has taken to address the legislation in terms of what we believed would be a better outcome in relation to an industry code but, generally, our efforts to ensure that people, particularly those in rural and regional Australia, can access a product at a competitive price and, as I said, that is provided pursuant to good service. I will seek further advice on the issue of multiple franchises, which the honourable senator suggests are in conflict with the act.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the government investigated whether multi-site franchising is being carried out through blind trusts?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —Not that I am aware of, but I will seek advice on that.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Domestic Airfares

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware that, only yesterday, Qantas announced that domestic airfares would increase by 7.5 per cent from 1 July 2000 and that this increase is directly due to the Howard/Lees GST? How is this possible when the government's own estimates, as contained in the ANTS package, predicted a 0.8 per cent decrease in the price effect for `air and space transport'? Given that the ACCC has considered this increase within its exploitation powers and has ticked off on this price increase, does this mean that each and every industry is able to get ticks from the ACCC for increases, even when the actual price increase is 1000 per cent more than that calculated by the Howard government?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator McLucas for that question. I do not know whether there is some lack of coordination between the two chambers and the questions committee, but a very similar question was asked in the other place.
—Good, you have a chance to answer it then.
—I am not quite sure. I have actually got the same answer here, Senator, so I am very happy to relate it, but I would just urge the questions committee of the Labor Party to get its act together.
—Senator Kemp, I draw your attention to the question.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was just saying that this question has been answered in the other place. On 28 September, Qantas announced increases of 7.5 per cent in domestic airfares for travel undertaken after 1 July 2000, reflecting the impact of the GST. The decision is a commercial issue for the domestic airlines. If the increase is not justified, the ACCC has been given powers to take action. These price increases affect only domestic air travel. International air travel and the domestic legs of international flights are GST free and the prices of these should fall as a result of tax reform. So the senator can see that there are a variety of impacts from the GST.

answer.para: The different treatment of domestic and international air travel is in line with standard international practice in value added taxes. Making international air travel taxable would simply encourage the purchase of travel offshore, denying Australian businesses market share. As the senator indicated, estimates of changes in industry prices as a result of tax reform were published in a new tax system statement. para.inline: DETENTION OF PERSONNEL IN EAST TIMOR

speech.para: SENATOR COONEY asked SENATOR HILL, representing the Prime Minister, on 27 September 1999:

. Persons apprehended by members of INTERFET are delivered to a Force Detention Centre, temporarily located at Dili airfield, to which the International Committee of the Red Cross is allowed full access. All detainees will be treated in accordance with fundamental humanitarian standards.

. INTERFET's detention authority is derived from United Nations Security Council Resolution 1264 and is necessary and incidental to the accomplishment of the mandate. It is not possible to restore peace and security in East Timor without having the power to detain persons who commit serious crimes or who obstruct the accomplishment of INTERFET's mission. INTERFET has established a Force Detention Centre in Dili which currently has a capacity to hold 15 detainees.
. INTERFET detention policy is predicated on the continued functioning of Indonesian law enforcement authorities in East Timor.

. The Force Detention Centre has held a total of 43 people so far, including Pro-Independence and Militia.
. 37 have been released:
- 2 to Indonesian Police;
- 9 to Indonesian Armed Forces;
- 7 to UNAMET CIVPOL;
- 18 released under their own recognisance; and
- 1 has elected to stay of his own free will.

subdebateinfo.title: Business Tax Reform: Capital Gains Tax

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) to questions without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to the goods and services tax.

Today we witnessed yet again an inept and incompetent display by the Assistant Treasurer in answering questions in his own portfolio area. We know that the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, has the responsibility for taxation in the portfolio split between him and the Treasurer. During the whole GST debate we found Senator Kemp totally unable to answer questions of detail on how the GST would impact on ordinary Australians. Again today, when asked a specific question about the Ralph review and capital gains tax, Senator Kemp was once more unable to provide an answer. He filled the time with bluster and with counter-questions, and posed in terms of political point scoring rather than hew to the task of providing information to this chamber which, after all, is what question time is all about and what it is his job to deliver.

There are two things that I want to touch on today: first, about the GST and, second, about capital gains tax. The opposition warned, when the GST came in, that the estimates about the price impact of the GST were wrong, that they would be a lot higher than what the government was alleging. Now we have the National Architects Advisory Centre saying that house prices are being artificially inflated across Australia by 20 per cent. So, with the price of housing artificially inflated by 20 per cent, the GST then comes along as another 10 per cent on top of that. Who gets slugged? The ordinary wage and salary earner who buys a house. And not all of them buy new houses, but the advantage that the government claims to have built into its package for new home buyers is eroded considerably as well.

But it is not only home buyers that are getting slugged. We heard today that Qantas are increasing their airfares by 7.5 per cent, when the government estimated that in this category of travel the cost to ordinary Australians would in fact decrease by 0.8 per cent. And when are Qantas increasing their airfares? On 1 July next year, the very day the GST comes in. So it is on those increased airfare prices that you will pay the extra 10 per cent. Airfares for Australians will not decrease by 0.8 per cent; they will go up much more than 10 per cent across Australia. So despite all this bleating we hear from the government that says, `But don't worry. You'll get a tax cut and the tax cut will offset the price hikes', the price hikes are going to offset the tax cuts and there will be losers in middle Australia and in low income Australia right across the board with the introduction of the GST.

If you do not believe me, just listen to the Reserve Bank of Australia. What did the government say? The government said, `Inflation in the second year after the GST will be 1.9 per cent.' You slug Australia with a 10 per cent GST and the government says, `Prices will only go up by 1.9 per cent.' What does the Reserve Bank of Australia, the independent banking authority in this nation, say? It says now that it will be about five per cent. Once again we find that the so-called tax cuts that are meant to compensate Australians for a price hike under a GST will not be adequate. The so-called `no-one loses' theory is pitched in the belief that inflation will be 1.9 per cent—not five per cent, as the Reserve Bank says—and that price increases in housing, as we now see, and in airfares, as we now see, will not occur.

Today we also questioned the minister about the capital gains tax that is proposed in the Ralph report, the capital gains tax that the government is proposing to introduce. A noted Australian professor of taxation law, the Professor of Tax Law at Deakin University, Professor Krever, who was an independent consultant to the Ralph inquiry, says that the government has got it wrong; that the changes to capital gains tax will benefit only the very wealthy or the husbands or wives of the very wealthy. They are the only two categories that will benefit. If they benefit, someone loses. The question is: who loses? The rest of us lose because, if you cannot make these tax changes stack up, then wage and salary earners—who have to pay every red cent of taxation due—pick up the weight that the very wealthy in this country avoid through the proposed changes in capital gains tax. This is not the Labor Party asserting this; this is the independent consultant of the Ralph review, a distinguished professor of taxation law in Australia, Professor Krever, who is asserting this. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the motion to take note of Senator Kemp's answer. In particular, I wish to talk about the capital gains tax regime for Australia, which is currently completely out of order with regard to the rest of the world. In our nation, which depends on capital flowing in and out of it efficiently and being invested here to create jobs and wealth for everyone and for governments to take their share of it to do whatever we need to do for education, health, safety et cetera, we need a successful business enterprise economy.

speech.para: There have been many complaints about the capital gains tax regime in Australia. The Ralph committee has looked at it in depth, and the government has accepted the recommendations from that committee and has announced its decision. Professor Krever is just one voice, one academic, complaining about the system. Perhaps he has a chip on his shoulder about his views about that.

For Senator Cook's benefit, I refer to a book by Robert Barrow called Getting it right: markets and choices in society. On page 120 is a graph showing the share of income tax paid by the top 0.5 per cent of income distribution in the USA over the period from 1960 to 1990. The graph quite clearly shows that, when the rates were put up in the USA in the 1980s, the total amount of tax paid by the rich 0.5 per cent went down in the USA but, when the rates were reduced in the 1990s, the tax paid by those people basically went up. The same thing happened in Ireland, I might add. I will quote from an article in the Irish Times of 28 July this year:

In the same budget the Government slashed the basic rate of capital gains tax from 40 per cent to 20 per cent. Again, we were told that this would cost the Exchequer money; in fact, receipts from capital gains tax jumped by more than 75 per cent.
I repeat: `receipts from capital gains tax jumped by more than 75 per cent'. That is the important thing. This is not being driven by envy, which is something that seems to drive the Labor Party.

We are on about the practicalities of how the economy actually works and what can be done to make it work. I am quoting US examples and again the Irish example: reduce the tax rates and you will get more income. I will also quote from the Australian of 21 September, on capital gains tax:
The Centre for Policy Research of the American Council for Capital Formation in July completed a macro-economic analysis of the 1997 cuts to the US capital gains tax.

I might add that the Clinton administration reduced capital gains tax from 28 per cent to 20 per cent in order to be competitive, and it was matched by the Blair government doing a similar thing in the UK, so that their economies were competitive with regard to capital. We have no choice: we have got to be competitive. The article continues:
The most important conclusions were that the reduction in the individual CGT top rate, from 28 per cent to 20 per cent, reduced the net cost of capital for new investment by about 3 per cent.
That is a staggering result for the USA. Further on, the same article says:
Rather than reduce the US federal revenues, the study shows that the stimulus to economic growth as a result of the lower CGT has added $US5 billion to federal tax receipts.
I repeat: `$US5 billion to federal tax receipts'.
Another study referred to in the same article shows that:
. . . despite the 1997 cuts to the US CGT tax rate, and the corresponding boost to economic growth, most countries still tax individual and corporate capital gains more lightly than the US.

A total of 24 industrial and developed countries were surveyed. Prepared by Arthur Andersen, the study shows that short-term individual gains are taxed at 39.6 per cent in the US compared with an average of 19.4 per cent for the sample as a whole.
The same article quotes again the US rates for capital gains tax, even though they have been reduced down to basically 20 per cent, and says that the survey showed:
. . . that individual Australians have the highest CGT of the countries surveyed—48.5 per cent both short and long term, the same as the maximum individual tax rate.

Everyone knows that this has got to be changed. The Labor Party has been saying for some years that we need to encourage venture capital and that we need investment in this country in IT, venture capital and the other growth industries. This cannot be done unless the capital gains tax regime is changed, and that is what the government proposes to do. It is fair; it is sensible; and the economy and the government will be better off. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I also wish to take note of the answer from Senator Kemp today when I asked whether the government was aware that house building prices were being pushed up by as much as 20 per cent in anticipation of the GST. Senator Kemp waffled on and waffled on and never really answered my question at all. This is an extremely serious question. He went on about how the house building sector is booming and how more Australians are able to buy homes.

speech.para: Of course, what is happening is that people who want to buy, build or renovate homes are doing it now before the GST comes in so that they do not have to pay the GST, because they think it is going to be cheaper to do it now rather than later. What is happening is that some building companies are apparently lifting charges to take advantage of this high demand. It is not a normal boom in building. It is a boom because people want to avoid the GST—which seems to be beyond the comprehension of Senator Kemp. Apparently, Archicentre have reported that some bricklayers have reportedly already lifted their fees from $450 per 1,000 bricks to $1,000 per 1,000 bricks, an increase of more than 100 per cent. Of course, in the rural and regional areas, this is devastating for people. It is much harder for them and they have to wait much longer to build or renovate, and so of course they are being disadvantaged unreasonably.

We also heard that Qantas have confirmed that their airfares are going up by 7.5 per cent from 1 July next year. As my colleague Senator Cook said, the government declared that the cost of an airline ticket would decrease by 0.8 per cent. Of course, as everybody in this chamber knows, I come from the most beautiful state in Australia, and that is Queensland. Queensland happens to be a tourist state. We depend on tourism for our economy and our jobs and we love to share our state with other people. Of course, if the cost of airline tickets goes up—and it will—this will disadvantage Queensland. Queensland tourism will be disadvantaged; fewer people will come and they will have less money to spend. This will also affect jobs. The building sector in Queensland is in dire straits with building costs going up and, if the price of airline tickets goes up, this will be devastating for Queensland.

I have to ask: why is this happening? Does this government have something against Queensland? Does this government have something against the tourist states? It is absolutely diabolical. As far as I am concerned, this is an attack on Queensland as a tourist state, and I am sure it will affect tourism in the other states. I do not think the premiers of these states will be too happy at all.

talk.start.para: —What about Tasmania?

—Absolutely. I must say, Senator Sherry, that I regard Tasmania as the second most beautiful state in Australia. I love going to Tasmania. Tasmania has so much to offer the tourist industry. Tasmania is in dire need of jobs and a boost in the economy. Not only will this disadvantage Queensland tourism through lack of jobs and the increase in the cost of accommodation; it will also disadvantage states like Tasmania, from which so many of my colleagues here come and which, I must admit, is quite a beautiful state.

speech.para: When I ask Senator Kemp serious questions about housing and the GST, I would urge him to actually try to answer me instead of waffling on about how interest rates have gone down, how housing is far more affordable and how mortgage rates have gone down. He did not even try to answer. He obviously did not have a brief. That is fine. If he did not have a brief, he could have said that he would get back to me at a later date and that he would let this side of the chamber know what was going on. Obviously, once again he did not. talk.start.para: —Senator Gibbs has referred to the impact of the GST on house prices. Not only do the Labor Party have no policies on tax or just about anything else, but their level of knowledge about this topic in particular is also pretty patchy. The first thing to be said about this topic is that it needs to be put into perspective.

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Hill, Senator Carr and Senator Cook, would you like to conduct your conversation outside, so that Senator Coonan can actually address the chamber. I am interested in hearing what she has to say and not what the three of you have to say.

—Very wise, too, Madam Deputy President. For instance, Senator Cook makes no mention at all of the broader implications for the construction industry. If you are going to talk about the cost of housing, put it into perspective and look at the cost of construction and where that falls. I actually have a bit of information about this. The effective level of work in the industry varies from economic modeller to economic modeller, but certainly it is accepted that house construction prices will rise by about five per cent. That seems to be correct. However, it must be said that the package, of course, contains measures to maintain affordability of a residential dwelling, and that is not only due to favourable interest rates—the best interest rate climate since the war—but the First Home Owners Scheme will assist first home buyers to make that first important purchase. And existing home owners will, of course, benefit from their homes increasing in value.

speech.para: A lot has been said about the net effect on demand. It must be expected that there will be a number of industry participants who might be concerned about the effect of GST on the business, but in both its implementation and subsequent changes to business practice, it is clear that there will be some changes to the industry. Of course, the most immediate effect is called the `pull forward of demand' pre-GST and overseas experience suggests that the prospect of higher costs in fact does that. Then, of course, there is a levelling out after the GST.

In New Zealand there was a boost to new dwelling construction in the two quarters ahead of the introduction of the GST and there was a similar rise in the three and four quarters ahead of the GST's introduction in Canada. The Housing Industry Association estimates that, according to Australia's proposals, a pull forward of some 10 per cent of annual demand over 21 months is most likely, which equates to 13,000 new dwelling starts worth over $1.4 billion—a substantial boost to the construction industry.

There is also the reciprocal effect of the `drop-off', which nobody has bothered to mention today, after the introduction of the GST, although it must be noted that the latest BIS Shrapnel report suggests that in fact there will be a quick recovery for the industry in 2001-02. In fact, the Econtech report in its conclusion expects `a positive outcome for the Australian economy and the building and construction sector as a result of the introduction of the GST, as a better economy leads to increased demand for new construction activity'.

The news gets better. Nobody has mentioned the special concessions for the construction industry in the package. There are number of special concessions that will benefit the construction industry from the implementation of the new tax system. I have mentioned the First Home Owners Scheme, but builders will, of course, benefit from a marginal tax scheme that has been described by Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu's director, Ross Abbey, as `effectively reducing the GST liability on the taxable supply of freehold land, the sale of stratum units or the long-term lease of property'.

Before we get excited about the construction industry, it is very important that Senator Gibbs, Senator Cook and all of those on the other side of the chamber actually put it in balance: don't put out to people listening that there are negatives in this package. It is an overwhelmingly positive package and one that is likely to finally deliver a competitive tax system for this country.

talk.start.para: —I rise to take note of answers from Senator Kemp today, or perhaps we could refer to them as non-answers. Far be it from me to make any comments about Senator Kemp's competency in failing to give us an adequate answer, but why in fact would he want to relay to this chamber the truth of what is actually happening with this government's GST package? The house of GST cards is falling down around their feet probably sooner than most of us expected. The announcement yesterday by Qantas of a 7½ per cent increase in airfares from 1 July next year will have a major impact across this country in relation to tourism not only in Queensland and Tasmania but also in my constituency of the Northern Territory.

speech.para: One thing needs to be said about people who live in the Northern Territory and probably also in Far North Queensland and Western Australia—that is, by and large, Territorians rely on the airfares to keep in contact with their extended families. They rely on that airfare—and the dry season in Darwin is commonly known as the `granny' season when elderly relatives from interstate actually fly to the Northern Territory, and there are good reasons for that. It is very difficult to live in remote parts of this country away from close family and friends for long periods of time.

Families spend most of their time saving up for airfares and for their holiday to go south. It is also common at Christmas time to talk about `going south'. There is a large exodus from Darwin and Alice Springs, and no doubt from places like Broome and even Weipa, as families in remote parts of this country fly south and have Christmas with their loved ones. This is another example of where the GST is going to impact on the 80 per cent of Australians who, of course, have an income of less than $50,000. It is another example of this GST package hitting families in this country.

There was an estimated decrease in airfares of 0.8 per cent. That has gone by the by now. For example, a one-way Darwin to Sydney airfare currently on a 21-day advance purchase, which is what most families would actually aim for because it is known to be cheaper, costs $729, but on 1 July it will go up to $783. If you are just travelling from Darwin to Adelaide, you are looking at an increase of $44, from $579 to $623—so $44 one way and about $88 to $90 return. When you are talking about a family of four or five, it is a lot of money.

The government opposite us would say, `Yes, but that's going to be offset by tax cuts.' If I am earning around $35,000, I probably will be about $20 a week better off. But, if you stood here day after day and listened to this government prattle on about these tax cuts, $20 is going to go an awful long way by their estimation. It is going to go, they believe, an awful long way in the increase in airfares, the increase in house insurance policies that we are now seeing happening, the increase in the building industry and the increase in some of the items that they will buy on a day-to-day basis such as clothing.

But they will say, `What about the decrease we have seen as some of the wholesale sales tax has come off?' I put it to you that the number of times Territorians fly south far in excess outweigh the number of times they buy a washing machine or a television, which is probably only once or twice in the lifetime of their family. A lot of faith is being put in these illustrious tax cuts as opposed to the large increase in cost we are seeing on goods and services that are being provided—tax cuts that were based on an inflation rate of 1.9 per cent that, as Senator Cook has reminded the chamber today, is now up near five per cent.

We do not get answers from Senator Kemp, not because, I believe, he is incompetent in giving us the answers—although some of my colleagues probably have that view—but because I do not think that, if I were in his shoes, I would want to reveal the true facts. The true facts are, as the Labor Party have said time and time again, that the GST is going to impact on families, impact on 80 per cent of the people in this country, not the top 20 per cent of high income earners. It is going to have a significant impact on their lifestyle.

talk.start.para: —Today, we have seen a real scattergun approach from the Labor opposition in relation to the issues raised at question time, again basically to paper over their own lack of policy and the fact that they have not done any of the hard work in terms of alternative policy development to provide an alternative to the government's initiatives, particularly with regard to tax reform. We have heard them raise today the issue of the effect of the goods and services tax on airfares and on housing, and we have heard criticism of the government's new business tax system reforms in relation to capital gains tax.

speech.para: Let me just take up the issue of airfares. The Labor Party's criticism of the government in this regard has been based on an announcement by Australia's domestic airlines that airfares are going to increase by 7½ per cent after July next year when the goods and services tax comes into operation. The first point that needs to be made is that this is a commercial decision made by the airlines. If they cannot justify that price increase, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission will be investigating their price rises.

But, more importantly, the point needs to be made that the government said that there would be a range of price effects as a result of the introduction of the goods and services tax. Overall, the average price effect of the goods and services tax in terms of the con sumer price index will be 1.9 per cent, but obviously some goods and services will rise by more than that overall 1.9 per cent inflation effect. Some goods and services will rise by 1.9 per cent, some will rise by less than that and some will actually fall in price. Most importantly, a wide range of manufactured goods will fall substantially in price, and that is a very important issue for my state of South Australia, which produces motor vehicles and white goods. The prices of those items will fall substantially.

In addition to that, we have the substantial personal income tax cuts. Money in the pocket from those income tax cuts will be available to enable people to offset those items that rise in price by more than the 1.9 per cent. I put it to the Labor Party that, as was indicated in all of the work done on the new tax system—the research, the hearings that we conducted through the committees and so on when this policy was developed and when it was implemented through the legislation passed in this chamber—it is very clear that Australians overall will be better off as a result of the introduction of the new tax system, when you combine the effects of the personal income tax cuts with the price effect of the GST and, in particular, those items that will fall in price.

In overall terms, people will have more money in their pockets as a result of the tax cuts. As a result of the fall in the price of a number of goods they will be able to meet effectively those price increases that do result from the GST—airfares being one of those that has been identified today. In that context, we need to remember, of course, that probably half or thereabouts of air travel is undertaken by business travellers. For them there will actually be a fall in the cost of travel. So for business purposes—

talk.start.para: —That means that it is even worse for non-business travellers, does it not?

—This shows how naive Senator Sherry is. He interjects that it will be even worse for non-business travellers. It will not be. Because the cost of business travel will actually fall, the overall operating costs of businesses required to undertake that travel will fall, and therefore the price of the goods and services that they provide to their customers will fall. Again that reinforces the very point I was making—that the price of a number of good and services will actually fall to offset any direct price increases that private individuals have to face. That is the case, Senator Sherry. That is the first point that needs to be made in relation to air travel, in addition to those points I have made about income tax cuts and the price of other goods and services falling.

speech.para: It is only domestic airfares to which the goods and services tax will be applied. International airfares are treated as export income and therefore those prices will not be affected by the introduction of a GST, because it is zero rated. That means, as was mentioned a moment ago, that overall the price of air passenger transport will rise by only 0.8 per cent in the year 2000 as a result of these changes. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —The President has received a letter from Senator Forshaw proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

speech.para: The failure of the Federal Liberal-National Party Government to address the needs of rural and regional Australia as demonstrated by their lack of support for our major agricultural industries, failure to adequately support rural producers facing extreme financial difficulties and severe cuts to vital rural and regional programs and services.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

para.inline: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

talk.start.para: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.

—Not only is this matter of public importance supported by the opposition; it is also supported by the overwhelming majority of people in Australia. It is particularly supported by people living in rural and regional Australia, people who have been deserted by the Liberal and National parties virtually since they came to office in 1996. It was John Howard, the then Leader of the Opposition, who promised he would look after the battlers. When talking about battlers, there can probably be no group in Australia more deserving of attention than our farmers and people living in rural and regional Australia, who have been so badly hurt and so hard hit by the policies and decisions of this federal government and by the decisions of state governments of Liberal-National Party persuasion. I will come back to the election position in a minute, as we are seeing wholesale desertion by Australians living in rural and regional Australia when it comes to support for the coalition parties.

speech.para: People in rural and regional Australia have borne the brunt of the massive cuts introduced by this government when it came to office in 1996—cuts across a whole range of services such as education, health, local government, transport and so on. My colleague Senator Mackay will deal specifically with the impact of those massive cuts and other decisions of this government in respect of services for rural and regional Australia. I want to talk particularly about the impact upon those people who contribute so much to the wealth of this great nation, that is, farmers and employees of farmers in our great agricultural industries. This government, this federal Liberal-National Party government, has ignored their concerns.

Remember when this government came to office one of its first decisions was to abolish the then Department of Regional Development, the department that was specifically targeted at considering the needs of our farming and rural communities. Since then we have seen one ministerial disaster after another. John Anderson, who was the Minister for Primary Industries in the first Howard government, was so incompetent, so inept, that he had no-confidence motions passed against him at various meetings of farmers around this country. In the end, they had to promote him sideways to give the job to another National Party minister in Minister Vaile.

Minister Vaile's approach was that he would not adopt the haughty, landed gentry approach of Minister Anderson, an approach that was rejected by the people who had placed so much faith in this government; his approach was to be your friendly stock and station agent: `Come into my office, sit down, have a cup of coffee, discuss your problems and I will fix them.' That was Mr Vaile's approach. Looking at the agricultural sector in this country today, he has not fixed one problem; he has simply moved from one problem to the next. Any small moves that have been made by this government have only come about because of constant pressure being applied to previously Minister Anderson and now Minister Vaile.

Take, for instance, the pork industry. The pork industry in this country faced a major crisis due to significant levels of importation of pig meat and other pork products into this country. This government stood by and did nothing. Despite the pressure that was being applied, despite the appeals to Minister Anderson and to Mr Fischer, the then Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party, they did nothing until they were dragged kicking and screaming to the table and over a series of months dribbled out some assistance packages. But they came about well after the time had run out in which the decisions should have been made, and that is a problem that is endemic to this government. It allows the problems to go on and on before it takes any action. Unfortunately in some cases it is far too late. We have seen another example of that today, which I will come to in a minute. The government dribbled out these assistance packages but, as I said, much too late for many pork producers.

The problem, however, was that this government, in ignoring the plight of those producers, took the credit when prices increased recently. There has been a bit of an upturn in that industry, brought about not by the policies of this government but by a major disease outbreak in Malaysia whereby Australia was able to pick up some additional export markets, particularly to Singapore. This government tried to take the credit for something it had absolutely no control over.

We can then go to another significant industry in which we have seen a belated announcement today—again at the eleventh hour, or well past the eleventh hour—and that is the dairying industry. I do not want to get too involved in that debate because as Senator Crane, Senator Woodley and members of the rural and regional affairs committee know, we are about to bring down a report on this. But what has been the position of the federal government throughout this problem of deregulation in the dairying industry? It sat on its hands and did nothing. There has been a total absence of any national leadership.

talk.start.para: —It is a state matter.

—This is the problem, Senator Troeth. Senator Troeth says that it is a state matter. We have had the admission from the words of the parliamentary secretary. What have they said? They have said that it is a state matter. Notwithstanding the fact that they ripped hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars out of state finances in their first two budgets, they continue to say that this is a state matter. I say to the parliamentary secretary: it is not a state matter. Whilst regulation of the dairying industry may be controlled at the state level, there have been decisions made over a significant period of time in relation to the national dairying industry. Those decisions have come about because of national policies such as the determinations of national competition policy. I remind the parliamentary secretary that the national competition policy is not a state only matter; it looks at the issues of state regulation from a national perspective in trying to bring about competition on an equal basis or on a level playing field.
—One of the Labor Party's better policies.

—That is true, but I remind Senator Macdonald that the whole point is that you just do not have a policy. You also have to have leadership that drives that policy. Under the previous Labor government, we had ministers such as Mr Kerin. He set the dairying industry reform process on its way. He was able to convince the dairying industry of the need for reform. He was a magnificent minister for primary industries. He was then followed by Simon Crean. We had the Crean plan, which took the initiatives under John Kerin further, as did Bob Collins when he became minister.

speech.para: But what happened when the government changed from a Labor government to a Liberal-National Party government? What happened? Well, it all stopped. These people said that this was a state matter. Even though we know that the domestic market support scheme is going to cease at the beginning of July next year, this government has decided to do nothing to bring the states together in order to bring about a national position. What do we have now? We have a situation where the still remaining Premier of Victoria for a short time, Mr Kennett, decided to go it alone and sent the whole thing into a spin.

Today, in a last desperate act to try to keep some sort of measure of involvement in the process, the federal government has announced its response to the dairying industry package, something that has been called for for many months now. But, at the same time, we still have major states involved in the dairying industry saying that they are not on board with that decision. We have a whole series of positions across the states, and Victoria is in a real state of flux because nobody will really know which party will be governing that state until the outcome of the by-election towards the end of this year.

All through this, what has been the position of the Australian government? It has sat on its hands and done nothing. At the very time when we need national leadership to bring the states together to hammer out an agreement, knowing the deadline of 1 July next year is approaching, you have done nothing. It is a failure of national leadership. You can go through all those other issues we have had to look at over the last couple of years such as in the wheat industry, in the wool industry, in the salmon industry and in the forest industry where the minister for chainsaws is in charge of the forests—

talk.start.para: —Order! Please do not reflect upon a member in the other place.

—Mr Tuckey—and what happened? The policy fell to bits in total uproar with respect to his management of that portfolio. What we have seen over the last couple of years is that those people in the bush, in rural and regional Australia, placed their faith in this government in 1996. They voted for a change and they believed John Howard when he said that he was going to look after these battlers. What have they done? They have deserted in their hundreds of thousands, firstly in Queensland. They voted against the National Party government and elected quite a number of One Nation members to the Queensland parliament. The National Party was virtually wiped out in the bush there.

speech.para: Then in Tasmania the coalition government was thrown out of office, and Tasmania is a state which is extremely important in terms of rural and regional issues. It then happened in New South Wales. The Labor Party now holds a majority of seats outside the Sydney metropolitan area and the National Party lost a senator just like it did in Queensland in the last federal election. Then, to top it all off, it happened again in the Victorian elections recently when the Labor Party smashed the Liberal and National parties because of their desertion of people in the bush. (Time expired)

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
