(na) where the allocation of a *place ceases to have effect under Division 18, the approved provider must refund to the care recipient, or the legal personal representative of a deceased care recipient, any income derived from the accommodation bond and the retention amount that the approved provider received for that place and that has not been used in accordance with subparagraphs (n)(i) and (ii);

(nb) where a *place is transferred to another provider under Division 16 and the place would relate to a different *aged care service, the transferor must refund to the care recipient, or the legal personal representative of a deceased care recipient, any income derived from the accommodation bond and the retention amount that the approved provider received for that place and that has not been used in accordance with subparagraphs (n)(i) and (ii);
(nc) Rules for the refund of any income derived from the accommodation bond and retention amount under paragraph (na) or (nb) will be set out in the Residential Care Subsidy Principles.

This is the first of the measures that the Labor opposition is supporting which seek to quarantine the use of income derived from accommodation bonds and charges for use in upgrading capital infrastructure and ensure that where a provider closes down a facility they be required to refund the money where it is unspent. It is a similar measure to the one we just moved and lost in terms of the concessional supplement, but it is a slightly different debate because I do not think, on this occasion, the government will be arguing that this has nothing to do with capital. I am still flabbergasted by the response to the previous amendment with that defence. Clearly, if we could not get support for that, I suspect we will not get support for this either.

I want to raise the issues at stake in this because this is an even more important issue. The previous one was about the protection of taxpayers' funds and ensuring that they were used for the purposes for which they were intended. The Labor Party's deep concern is that there was no protection for those taxpayers' funds and no sufficient accountability to ensure that funds were used for purposes for which the parliament approved them. This is a measure which seeks to protect the interests of residents who are paying, if you like, user-pays fees for their accommodation, either in hostels or in nursing homes.

The government's aged care reforms introduced charges for nursing home residents to go with the bond system that was in place for hostels. The thrust of these amendments by the Labor Party is consistent with the approach we took in 1997, that we were looking to try to ensure that there was some protection for those residents and that the quite substantial amounts of money that they pay to their provider for accommodation purposes is used for those purposes. We are not convinced that there are sufficient protections in place for those residents.

With these amendments we have sought to put in place a system that ensures that where an older Australian pays money to a provider for the provision of the capital infrastructure of their nursing home or hostel the provider is required to use that money for that purpose. I think it is a fairly unremarkable initiative. We expressed our concern in 1997 that there was not enough of a link or enough protection to ensure that funds were used for the purposes that they were designed for. We still are of that view and I think the history of the last couple of years has added to our concern that providers are not required to commit those funds gathered from residents, in the form of fees, to the use of capital.

I think, for good accountability reasons, these amendments ought to be supported. From the industry's point of view, there is another problem, and it is one that will increasingly become a concern. The government's position on the last amendments indicated that there is this confusion now between what will be for daily needs and care and what will be for accommodation charges. There is a real risk that we will see the underfunding of daily care costs as the government seeks to blur the edges between the capital needs and the care needs.

Senator Herron's answer to the last amendment is a very interesting development in that when the care providers are arguing that they need more money to provide sufficient care the government is saying that the concessional resident's supplement that was for capital is now for capital and care and that somehow the boundaries have been blurred. I think there is a real risk that by blurring these boundaries, by failing to quarantine funds for capital, as was originally intended under the aged care reforms, we will see pressure building to use what was to be for capital for ongoing care needs, and we will end up in a situation, which a number of people in this chamber have gone on about at great length, where there will be a failure to address the capital needs of the nursing home sector.

I think these measures are important in terms of the consumer protections they provide to the residents. But I also think, in terms of dealing with government policy and development of the sector, it is an important policy imperative that we separate the two and that we give protection to the industry, if you like, to ensure that the money that has been designed to meet capital needs is used for capital needs. We will be moving these amendments along that track. Given that we have not been able to get support for less radical propositions, I do not expect to get any support from the chamber for these. However, I make my point quite strongly because I think it is going to be an important issue in the years to come.

I do want to say, particularly in terms of the bonds, that I would be interested in whether the minister can answer a couple of questions. I understand that paragraph 57(2) already requires providers to account for the income they derive from the bond and the capital expenditure, even if it does not require qua rantining the funds for capital works. The issue I want to raise with the minister is: what action does the department currently take to enforce compliance with that rule, to have providers account for the monies raised by the bonds; and what enforcement provisions have been put in place to ensure that the income derived from the accommodation bond is being used in accordance with the act? Perhaps that is a good starting point.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Senator Evans said he is flabbergasted. I am in complete agreement with him. I see from the dictionary that flabbergasted is `to be overcome with surprise and bewilderment.' He is certainly bewildered, because the amendment he has moved would require that all income from accommodation bonds be quarantined for capital works. I have travelled around many nursing homes and hostels in the last 40 years—certainly during election campaigns—and there have been many places that I have seen that certainly do not need money spent on capital works. This amendment would require that that money be quarantined for capital works. What if that place does not need money spent on capital works? Do we have to quarantine it, put it away somewhere, lock it up? He is certainly bewildered. I suggest that he come around with me some time to nursing homes and hostels—there are a wide variety—
—I've done my share, John.

—Not as much as Senator West and I have done, I assure you. As I said previously, because this is a similar amendment, if the money is not spent and buildings are not kept up to standard, they are not certified—they lose the ability to charge the bonds and, after 1 January 2001, they lose all funding. speech.para: As I said previously, these amendments could severely impact on care and services for residents and could prevent providers achieving accreditation by interfering with their ability to manage their finance. Once again, we are back to the `big brother', the good old ALP philosophy: control it all; make sure it reports to government; do not allow people to make their own decisions. The nursing homes are required to reach a certain standard—that is what accreditation is about—and, if they do not become certified, they lose the ability to charge those bonds.

talk.start.para: —The minister said, `They might not need it for accommodation.' Why would you then charge the pensioners of Australia and the older Australians who are residents in these places $12 a day if you think they do not need the capital? What you are saying to me is, `If they do not need the capital, you should not have a problem.' You introduced this fee and told the people they had to pay it to meet capital needs. They asked me whether it is being used for capital. You say, `If they don't need the capital, what is the problem?' I guess the people paying the fee would ask why they should be paying the fee. That is the question you have to answer.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —It improves the standard of care. It is spent on improving the standard of care to the residents. That is the purpose of injecting more money into the system—so either it can be spent on capital works or it can improve the quality of care that is provided. But in either case it must reach the standards for certification.

—I want to indicate that the Democrats will not be supporting this amendment nor the next two. As far as I can see, this is going over old ground again. We had the same debate at some length back in 1997 when my colleague Senator Woodley debated the original bill. At that time, after lengthy debate, the Democrats acknowledged that leaving aged care providers with absolutely no flexibility in how to allocate the money they receive from fees and charges might be counterproductive. I seem to remember that there was some discussion about whether a similar ALP amendment would mean that providers with facilities which already met the appropriate standards would be required to keep on upgrading those standards. You might imagine moving to gold taps in the bathroom or the like to use the funds for that purpose. I think that is what would happen. It is hardly likely that a nursing home would return funds; they would just go on spending them on unnecessary materials. For the record I would like to quote Senator Woodley during that debate when he said:

speech.para: In the initial phase, certainly we would want all of the money to be used for capital, retiring debt, et cetera. But down the road, does there come a point at which a provider has done everything he can possibly do? What does he then do with the income? It seems to me that, once you have done everything to bring the facility up to scratch, there may be the point at which you would want to allow the use of income for other things.
At that time, the Democrats successfully moved an amendment to the opposition's amendment which would require that:
. . . the approved provider must use the income derived from the accommodation bond and the retention amount in the following ways:

debateinfo.title: SUPERANNUATION CONTRIBUTIONS AND TERMINATION PAYMENTS TAXES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 August, on motion by Senator Ellison:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —For the third time in just over two years, the Senate is being asked to consider detailed changes to the government's flawed superannuation surcharge tax policy. On this occasion, there seems to be a begrudging acceptance of these changes before us by some in the superannuation industry, which is so shell shocked after three years of the Howard government that it is grateful for any scraps that fall off the Treasurer's table from time to time. I say there is a begrudging acceptance because one gets the impression that the industry would prefer to see the surcharge dispatched with rather more than more fiddling from the Assistant Treasurer.

speech.para: There are others in the industry who believe that the changes before us are an outrage in that they apply retrospectively, a point which is all but acknowledged by the government. It is on this point that Labor has a problem with this bill and will be moving an amendment that will prevent the retrospective operation of this bill. The Senate should very carefully consider legislation which applies any retrospective penalty on a person who has already complied with the law as it is written. Senator Kemp has maintained that there is nothing wrong with the current legislation. If that is the case, why is there a need for this amending legislation in the first place?

In addition, Labor will be moving a second reading amendment, to be moved by my colleague Senator Sherry, which urges the government to address the unfair circumstances that currently exist for some mineworkers at Pasminco sites around Australia. These workers receive superannuation based on their base rate of pay of around $25,000 per year. However, because of working a 12-hour shift, the workers actually incur a surcharge tax liability which they are forced to pay, despite getting superannuation contributions based only on a much lower rate of pay. Clearly, this is inequitable—just another of the many inequities of this flawed policy—and should be addressed by the government. A restriction on opposition parties initiating tax legislation in the Senate is why the opposition will not be moving a specific amendment.

Most measures in this bill improve and, to the extent that it is possible, simplify the operation of the superannuation surcharge tax, and Labor will be supporting them. On this occasion the government appear to have consulted widely in formulating this bill, which they seem very eager to have passed. As I said earlier, there was not complete agreement of the government's position on the retrospective calculation of the surchargeable contributions. Compliance costs associated with the changes are claimed by the government to be low, although anything related to compliance with the surcharge is much more likely to cost a bomb rather than cost little.

To the extent that it is possible, Labor agrees that some measures in this bill improve and simplify the operation of the superannuation surcharge tax, and we will support these aspects of the bill. The outstanding issue is the abolition of the advance instalment requirement, which should not have been a part of the bill in the first place. It was only Senator Kemp's stubbornness which saw it remain as part of the bill. Senator Sherry will have more to say about that, I am sure.

A number of the changes, however, are chiefly designed to address the legality of the surcharge tax on defined benefit schemes, particularly those on a `contributions holiday' and those who are unfunded and make notional contributions. This aspect of the surcharge is presently the subject of a Federal Court challenge, which may come as news to the government and its advisers, who surprisingly indicated, in evidence to the committee which examined this bill, that they were not aware of the court challenge. But perhaps it will not come as news to the government and its advisers, as one could be forgiven for assuming that it is the likelihood that the govern ment will lose the case which has prompted these changes.

A senior superannuation lawyer and outstanding critic of the surcharge tax, Mr Noel Davis from Clayton Utz, together with Mr Chris Beeny from Mallesons and others who handle corporate defined benefit funds, are unhappy about the retrospective nature of the bill, which will require some superannuation funds to recalculate their surcharge tax liability. Mr Davis and Mr Beeny, who work as superannuation lawyers and, one could argue, benefit from a complex tax law, actually want to see the surcharge collection method scrapped. However, the government is unlikely to support a scrapping of the surcharge tax, despite it being a complete embarrassment, despite it being an albatross around the government's neck. The recommendation from Mr Davis and Mr Beeny and others is that, at the minimum, the government should ensure that this legislation does not operate retrospectively. Labor is inclined to support this view.

The requirement that super funds only need provide information to fund members if requested by the fund members represents a substantial cost saving to funds with a majority of members who do not pay the surcharge tax. However, it also means that fewer people would be aware that their super fund is reporting contributions received to the ATO, regardless of whether they pay the tax. It in effect reduces the transparency of the compliance costs of this tax in a way which I am sure the government is quite happy about. While drawing attention to this fact, Labor will not be opposing this measure, as it will result in cost reductions and a higher retirement income for working Australians.

Preliminary discussions with the Institute of Actuaries have revealed a range of technical problems with the bill relating to definitions of a number of terms. These definitional issues would ordinarily be issues about which Labor would propose amendments, but I understand that the government may be considering amendments as a result of these discussions.

The superannuation surcharge tax is a world's worst practice tax legislation and administration. The super tax is supposed to be levied on some 355,000 higher income earners and collect approximately $500 million per annum. Instead, due to the government's desire to keep its promise not to introduce any new taxes or increase any existing levies, the collection mechanism chosen has cost all eight million superannuation fund members the high price of reduced retirement incomes through increased administration costs as a minimum. Some low and middle income earners who did not provide their tax file numbers to their superannuation fund or the Australian Taxation Office—and whom the ATO cannot find cross-matching data on—are also likely to pay this tax.

The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia estimates that the cost to super funds in administration and collection of the super tax is in excess of $190 million. Evidence to the committee from Mr Noel Davis that the industry's reporting costs in the first year of operation of the super tax were some $270 million to enable the government to collect $340 million of tax revenue is clear evidence that this tax is not only inefficient but is inequitable. For all eight million superannuation fund members to have to pay for the collection of a tax which is supposed to be levied on only higher income earners is grossly inequitable. The government should be ashamed.

Answers to questions placed on notice confirm that the ATO itself has spent in excess of $23 million, with the Department of Finance and Administration and Comsuper spending $3.4 million. That adds up to approximately $27 million spent by the government in collecting this tax, meaning that all Australian taxpayers have shelled out for this tax, which is supposed to be on higher income earners. Remember, many funds, particularly industry funds, and many low and middle income earning members will go on incurring costs when they have few fund members who actually pay the tax.

The ATO has also confirmed that it had issued some $454 million of 1996-97 assessments, of which only $347 million had been collected by 30 June 1998. Some $86 million of amended and original assessments were issued in February 1999, bringing the total expected revenue for the financial year 1996-97 to $540 million, some $60 million more than the $480 million estimated for the 1997-98 financial year. Some $100 million has been collected since 1 July 1998, with approximately $76 million outstanding, again indicating revenue in excess of projections.

In February 1999, the ATO issued 66,500 surcharge tax assessments to persons who had not provided their tax file numbers to their superannuation fund or the ATO. While the ATO anticipates that all of these assessments will go to higher income earners, there are bound to be some who are not higher income earners yet will still receive an assessment from the tax office. This new tax is starting to bite the government, and it is the opposition's intention to ensure that all Australians know that Mr Howard has not only reneged on his promise but also lumbered eight million Australians with the most cumbersome tax in the history of taxation.

The figures I have mentioned suggest that many more people are paying more surcharge tax than the government estimated. This is expected to increase as employers are now required to provide superannuation information on group certificates, which will lessen the opportunity for surcharge avoidance. There is little doubt that the surcharge tax is an embarrassment to the government, particularly the Treasurer. Along with the GST, it represents poor tax administration and collection.

The Senate Economics Legislation Committee examined this bill and recommended that the Senate pass it subject to discussions between industry representatives and the government. These discussions have taken place and the government has indicated that it may move two technical amendments on the advice of the Institute of Actuaries and consulting actuaries William M. Mercer. Labor should support these amendments. Labor senators recommended that the bill be supported after the government address the issues of the retrospective aspects of the changes to the calculation of the surcharge and the fact that some workers are paid SG on a low base but are forced to pay the surcharge tax due to allowances and overtime.

talk.start.para: —You will live to regret this.

—I will debate you on the 7.30 Report any time you like to appear on that show, Senator. The government's bill will retrospectively apply amendments designed to address the legality of the surcharge tax on defined benefit schemes, particularly those on a `contributions holiday' and those who are `unfunded' and make `notional' contributions.
—You have done a big shift. You have done a Nick Sherry.
—Order, Senator!

—It is all right, Mr Acting Deputy President. The actuarial practices and methods of calculating the surcharge are presently the subject of a Federal Court challenge, which it appears the government is not confident of winning. It appears that the likelihood of the government losing the court case is what has prompted it to make the changes to abolish the advance instalment. In other words, it is an attempt to placate the industry in return for industry accepting the changes to the calculation of the surcharge which will retrospectively apply to a minority of funds.

speech.para: Labor will be moving an amendment to prevent the bill from operating retrospectively. This amendment may have an impact on revenue that the government believes is owing from funds who reported nil surchargeable contributions. The extent of this revenue is unknown according to verbal advice from the ATO. However, the arguments against this legislation are overwhelming. First, Senator Kemp has said in evidence to the committee that the government is happy with the existing legislation. That is right. Senator Kemp has said, `From our point of view, the legislation is sound.' If that is the case, Senator Kemp, why then the need to change it? Nothing to say? No interjection at this point?

talk.start.para: —I will have plenty to say. You have done a Nick Sherry. It will come back to haunt you.
—If you think the legislation is sound, Senator Kemp, why are we standing here today debating it?
—Order! Senator Conroy, I invite you to direct your comments through the chair. Senator Kemp, I invite you to use more parliamentary language, please.
—All I said was that he has done a Nick Sherry.
—You are out of order, Senator Kemp.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Second, funds who notified a return to the ATO of nil, based on the current legislation, will have to incur costs in recalculating a new return. Chris Beeny from Mallesons estimated in evidence to the committee that the cost would be approximately $40,000 to $50,000 for some funds. That cost would be borne by all fund members, not just those who are liable for the tax again, proving the inequity and injustice of this tax.

speech.para: Third, most funds may not have the information available to them to recalculate the liability under the new laws. In many cases, the systems have changed since the 1997 and 1998 returns were made. Fourth, systems changes to retrieve information could have implications for the Y2K security procedures funds are currently undertaking. Fifth, this bill will retrospectively change the existing law. That amounts to a denial of right to take legal action against existing legislation if the bill is changed retrospectively.

Sixth, the government has claimed that less than 1,500 funds reported nil contributions in the period in question. That is less than five per cent of all 180,000 superannuation funds. If, as Senator Kemp claims, its existing legislation is sound and such a small percentage of funds did not report as the tax office may have liked, why is the government pursuing a retrospective amendment for such a small number of funds? The government has not identified any revenue with this measure, so it cannot be to chase more revenue. No revenue—so what is happening, Senator Kemp, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President?

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak on the second quarterly report of the Chief Executive Officer of ARPANSA, the regulatory authority which was established this year under the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Act. That act came into force on 5 February and the accompanying regulations on 17 March 1999. These dates are particularly significant since there was a six-month transition period inserted into the act during which all Commonwealth agencies were to apply for licences to permit their involvement in the operation of radiation sources, facilities and nuclear installations. That six-month period has now passed and all Commonwealth facilities must now be licensed.

One of those facilities now licensed by ARPANSA is the Lucas Heights complex, which is operated by ANSTO. Since ANSTO is the intended operator of the new nuclear reactor the government wants to build in Lucas Heights, I would like to comment on some of the incidents that have been referred to in this particular report. Although it did not actually occur during the quarter of this report, the fuel rod handling incident has received another special mention. This seems to be due to a decision by ANSTO to change the INES rating of the accident. The INES rating is a figure on an agreed scale—it is actually an internationally agreed scale—from level zero to level seven, zero being where there is no safety impact and seven where there is a major accident such as Chernobyl. The fuel rod accident was moved from zero to one on that scale.

The accident was examined extensively by the Economics References Committee during the recently completed inquiry into the new nuclear reactor. Some of the evidence that was received during those hearings demonstrated a fairly lax view of the seriousness of this particular incident. I note that a period of eight weeks elapsed between the accident and the provision of a submission on recovery procedures by ANSTO. Curiously, ARPANSA's review of that submission took less than 24 hours and the operation was completed the same day.

The next incident report relates to a damaged sewer pipeline at Lucas Heights. This problem was dealt with rapidly, but the blaming of subcontractors bears an intriguing resemblance to the major discharge of water into the Woronora River late last year.

Perhaps most significant in the ANSTO related issues covered in this report is the small mention of the Little Forest Burial Ground. It is understood that previous media reports led to this inclusion. So that it is clearly stated on the record, I will repeat the sentence from the report. It states:
In total approximately 47,600 packages of active waste, with a volume of 1,765 cubic metres, were buried in 77 three metre deep trenches.

This is in a suburban area, not part of the main ANSTO complex. So apparently ANSTO will be applying for a licence to operate the site. I should hope so. My under standing is that those same media reports which prompted a reference to this site in the ARPANSA report also suggested that there had been vandalism and theft of radiation monitoring equipment at the site.

We know very little about what is actually stored at Little Forest, which provided waste disposal for the Australian Atomic Energy Commission from 1960 to 1968. Certainly, there is uranium, cobalt, beryllium, small amounts of plutonium, traces of other isotopes and extensive low level radioactive waste. I hope that the commitment that has been given by ANSTO to make further investigations at the Little Forest Burial Ground in the context of the licensing process for Lucas Heights has been followed through. The Little Forest Burial Ground remains a major issue for the local community.

I conclude my remarks with a brief reference to the new nuclear reactor that has been promoted by this government. The ARPANSA report makes reference to the licence application for this new reactor, referring to it with the government's preferred phrase of `replacement reactor' when we know it is a new reactor. This report refers to materials which would be considered in investigating the licence application. Included were 73 public submissions. I hope these submissions have been treated seriously by ARPANSA. I hope that ARPANSA has been the regulator of government nuclear activities. I hope it will be the regulator of these activities. It should be. I am not confident of that. I understand that ARPANSA has now granted a site licence for the new nuclear reactor. The construction and operation of a reactor is not necessary. It is not appropriate. I reiterate the Democrats' opposition to Australia's continuing involvement in the nuclear fuel cycle. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak to the annual report of ESRA for 1997-98. It is the final report of that body. It effectively ceased operations in October 1998 after ceasing day-to-day operations upon the introduction of the government's privatised employment services scheme—Job Network—in May of last year.

talk.start.para: —A very successful scheme it is too.

—It is a great pity that the government chose to throw out ESRA with the rest of the CES based system of employment service delivery. I note the interjection from Senator Kemp, not that it is a successful scheme but, regardless of whether it is successful or not, it should have an appropriate regulatory and monitoring body. It is sad that they got rid of this body. It was a vital component of a well-run, effective network of case management and employment service provision, and it has been sorely missed since the introduction of the beleaguered Job Network to which Senator Kemp referred.

speech.para: The Australian Democrats have, on a number of occasions, listed our concerns with Job Network. We have voiced these concerns. Some of these concerns range from charging employers fees for services which they received for free under the CES, to cashing out training and support for job seekers, to leaving their employment welfare to the discretion of the individual provider and to making community services operate on a profit motive. There are many reforms which we believe should have been and can be made to Job Network to give job seekers their best chance of finding work in what is becoming a cutthroat labour market.

However, a key concern has always related to the protection of job seekers within this brave new world of privatised employment assistance—that is, the lack of an independent regulator to oversee service delivery and report on any problems that may emerge. ESRA performed this function under the old system. It received its funding from outside the department of employment and operated outside that department, protecting it from any conflicts of interest. It comprised consultative committees and a national board with a balance of parties—providers and interested parties such as welfare organisations and, of course, consumers of the employment services. It also produced regular reports on the outcomes of organisations. These functions are not being served under the current arguments, compromising transparency, accountability and market choice.

What the government has failed to understand in its refusal to set up an independent monitoring body to carry out the functions that were previously performed by ESRA is that, for a marketised system of service delivery to operate, for job seekers to have the same status as clients—as they are intended, according to government rhetoric—they must have access to independent information about the services competing for their custom. Instead, we have seen a trickle of information released by the department. Of course, both DETYA and the department responsible for workplace relations and small business are now responsible for the evaluation and the monitoring. It was months before any performance data was available on the performance of job agencies under Job Network. This information was quickly withdrawn after a brief appearance on the Internet. Job seekers are more likely to choose the agency with the greatest advertising power. It has been no surprise that the government owned Employment National has capitalised on the generous market share allocated to it by the government, certainly in the initial tender round.

It is also vital that job seekers be able to access a complaints mechanism. In 1997-98, 43 written complaints were lodged with and investigated by ESRA, and all were resolved by 30 June 1998. These complaints, according to page 38 of the report, covered instances of unsympathetic or rude case managers, communication difficulties, inappropriate refusals and referrals to case management, privacy breaches and unsatisfactory levels of service. Current arrangements place most responsibility for dealing with complaints with the agency itself. This is an unsatisfactory situation for job seekers, who are often reluctant to pursue claims against an agency through that agency.

With the second tender round now in progress, information on unsatisfactory performance by job agencies should be available to the department to make proper evaluations of job agency performance. With agencies now pursuing the resolution of complaints in-house, this information is less likely to be made publicly available. In the wake of the demise of ESRA, a qualitative monitoring process must be incorporated into Job Network to monitor the levels of client service provided by job agencies and to ensure that the department maintains the accounting of clients and outcomes and regularly makes public those results. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I wish to share with the chamber a Tasmanian good news story, and that is the story of the Tasmanian poppy industry. I wish to take this opportunity to shed light on the growth, benefit and strength of Tasmania's poppy industry, where we have become the largest producer of raw narcotic materials in the world. There are just two players in this Tasmanian success story, and they both operate from the north of the state. Glaxo Wellcome Australia Ltd is situated at Latrobe, and Tasmanian Alkaloids Pty Ltd is situated at Westbury.

speech.para: Poppy production in Australia is strictly regulated by federal and state governments, and Tasmania, being an island state and isolated, is favoured for security reasons. The Poppy Advisory and Control Board coordinates the regulatory and surveillance operations, and the Tasmanian Poppy Growers Association provides a healthy sounding-board and an information source for growers. The Tasmanian poppy industry was pioneered by Glaxo Australia in the early 1960s. Today it is one of the success stories of Australian agriculture and manufacturing. The industry's growth has been based on the innovative development and usage of technology in all aspects of the operation, and Tasmania's poppy crop provides world markets with a reliable and secure supply of alkaloids for analgesic medicines.

Poppy production has quite an interesting history. For example, in 1806 a complex chemical responsible for pain relieving properties was isolated from opium gum and called `morphine' after Morpheus, the Greek god of dreams. In 1831 a process for the extraction of morphine hydrochloride from opium gum was developed at Edinburgh University in Scotland. In the 1920s, Hungarian scientist Janos Kabay developed a process to extract morphine from dry poppy straw, which was an essential requirement for the future development of a mechanised harvest. The year 1951 saw Mr Stephen King, an agriculturalist, and Mr Bull, a chemical engineer, commence work on the production of poppy straw in Britain—on behalf of the Glaxo group—as an insurance against the unreliable supply of opium from traditional producers. Heavy rainfall resulted in low alkaloid concentration, however, and the attempt to grow poppies in Britain was abandoned in 1957. A search began for a more favourable climate and, in the 1960-61 season, trials were undertaken in New South Wales, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania. Poppies had been grown in Australia on a limited scale during World War II, but cultivation ceased after the war.

Tasmania was chosen as the location for all future development. In the 1964-65 season, the first commercial harvest of 52 hectares using 17 growers produced 140 kilograms of morphine alkaloid. Mr Stephen King moved to Tasmania in 1965 to supervise research and commercial production, and growers formed the Oil Poppy Growers Association. Thus a new Tasmanian industry was born. A reliable and productive cultivar suited to Tasmanian conditions was identified in 1969. A Glaxo factory was constructed at Latrobe in 1970 and, in the 1971-72 season, Glaxo for the first time produced sufficient morphine to supply the needs of Australia as well as New Zealand. In 1977 exports of poppy seed to the United States exceeded imports from the Netherlands for the first time. In 1985 continued growth in the industry resulted in Glaxo supplying 13 per cent of the world's requirements for opiate alkaloids.

Ten years later, in 1995, Glaxo Wellcome Australia—Glaxo having purchased the pharmaceutical company Wellcome—supplied 25 per cent of the world market. Approximately 90 per cent of all production was being exported. The success continues. Work has begun on planting the crop for the 1999-2000 season. It will be the biggest poppy crop ever planted in Tasmania and is expected to earn about $200 million for the state's economy. Using 1,400 growers statewide, the area of Tasmania's farmland planted with poppy has doubled in four years to 20,000 hectares. Cropping is mostly concentrated in the north-west and north-east of the state.

In the competition for fertile farmland and to drive the industry forward, producers offer free seed and professional advice from qualified field officers, drilling charges are paid, all herbicide costs are paid by the company and deducted from the final grower payment and harvesting and cartage is undertaken by the company at no cost to the grower. An innovative payment system guaranteeing minimum payments and a bonus incentive scheme ensure satisfied growers. Each year Tasmanian Alkaloids give their growers the chance to win a Mercedes Benz 180 motor vehicle. The company seek out a champion in the poppy industry to create a goal for all growers to strive towards in trying to improve the product.

This year's winners produced a crop which yielded 40 kilograms of alkaloid per hectare. This compares to a world average of 12 kilograms per hectare. The return was $8,763 a hectare, which is nearly three times the northern Tasmanian industry average of around $3,000 per hectare. The support of Tasmanian growers has been an integral factor in the success and growth of the poppy industry, and growers have displayed an ability to quickly adapt to the many improved practices targeted by the producers. Efficiency in providing a competitively priced product and aggressive marketing of the unsubsidised crop in the international arena have led to the industry meeting competition head-on from France, India, Hungary, Spain, Turkey, Poland, Yugoslavia and other countries.

Customers demand a reliable supply of quality products, which in turn enables them to supply quality products to their own markets. Glaxo Wellcome is recognised as being one of the world's largest opiate suppliers with exports to over 12 countries. Tasmania is pushing for more poppy exports to the United States, and a change of attitude by the United States Drug Enforcement Agency could result in increased Tasmanian narcotic raw material exports—which would be good news for the state. Unfortunately, the US specifies that 80 per cent of its imports must come from India and Turkey, with 20 per cent from the rest of the world. A relaxation of the US law to a 60 to 40 percentage split would enable the Tasmanian industry to grow significantly, and all parties are lobbying very strongly for this to occur.

Security of the product is extremely important. Tasmania has a worldwide enviably low level of poppy theft at 0.001 per cent. This compares with recent statistics suggesting a 30 per cent diversion from legitimate purposes of material in India and Turkey. All Tasmanian growers are issued with individual licences and these carry responsibilities and obligations which ensure that the industry maintains its status as the model of poppy production. The companies, growers, police and control board inspectors all play an important role in security and in the industry's future. As the industry grows, additional staff are employed by the companies and the control board, cars for field officers are required, new seeding drills and harvesters are purchased, additional trucks are required and additional laboratories are built.

The Glaxo Wellcome annual poppy crop is harvested and processed in Tasmania at Latrobe and the poppy capsules containing the medical alkaloids are processed and shipped to the Port Fairy plant in Victoria for extraction. The poppy seeds are cleaned and exported from Latrobe to the culinary food industry worldwide. Tasmanian Alkaloids has recently opened a new research and development laboratory in a three-year, $18 million expansion at its Westbury factory, and the company aims to keep all its value adding processes in Tasmania. With demand for poppy alkaloids to supply the legal pharmaceuticals market growing at the rate of five per cent a year, Tasmania now supplies half the world's morphine demands. Further favourable outcomes for the Tasmanian poppy industry are ensured. Successful partnerships with growers, profitable and reliable crop returns, the application of innovative technology, crop security, the capacity for rapid crop harvest and intake, aggressive marketing and a worldwide reputation for reliability and quality have all contributed to the building of a sustainable future for this outstanding industry. So it is not surprising that agricultural commentators from the ABC recently commented that, if you want to go to an interesting place in terms of agriculture, you should get a transfer to Tasmania. I thank the Senate.

subdebateinfo.title: Drug Detoxification Clinics: Dr Stuart Reece

talk.start.para: —I rise this evening to bring to the Senate's attention the impressive work being done by Dr Stuart Reece in his Brisbane drug detoxification clinic. Senators will be all too aware of the problems that drugs, particularly heroin, cause in this country. Dr Reece's work, along with the work of similar clinics around the country, has shown that it is possible to fight drug addiction. Despite the rhetoric coming from the Prime Minister's office about reducing crime and building communities, senators also need to be made aware of the obstacles that the federal government is putting in the way of effective treatment of drug addicts—but I will come to that later.

speech.para: Dr Reece started the naltrexone rapid detoxification unit in Brisbane in July last year. His clinic is combating more than just a health problem; it is combating social problems as well. Some of the people that he helps have a $500-a-day addiction. That level of addiction leads to all sorts of social problems such as violence, family breakdown and crime. Parliament, the government and the community in general have a big interest in helping to solve these problems. When people talk about the supposed high cost of treating heroin addicts, they seem to forget the cost of the alternatives. Treating people in hospital for heroin overdoses is extremely expensive, as is putting people in jail. Areas such as Inala and Ipswich have long felt the effect of drug related social problems. We owe it to the community, especially to the people in those drug ravaged areas, to help fight this problem in the most effective way we can.

Dr Reece faces enormous difficulties in providing his services to the people in most need. However, before I start talking about some of the problems that Dr Reece faces, I will talk about some of his success stories. If any of us here went to hospital and needed pain-killers, we would possibly be given five or 10 milligrams of methadone. One particular patient who came in to Dr Reece's clinic was using up to 200 milligrams of methadone a day. He was also taking half a gram of heroin a day, as well as one or two packets of valium a day—this was every single day. He underwent naltrexone treatment at the clinic nine months ago. He has been heroin free since then and is just now starting his own mechanics business.

Another young lady who underwent the treatment a year ago has stayed off heroin. She found a job, married and is now starting a family. Dr Reece also treated a computer programmer who had been sacked from his job because of the effects of his addiction on his life. Since the treatment, this man has gone from strength to strength, even so far as being able to get a new job that pays $150,000 a year.

They are some of the personal stories from the Brisbane clinic. The overall story is just as impressive. Since the clinic opened, they have treated about 500 patients. Their success rate—which is determined by seeing how many addicts stay off opiates for six, and then twelve, months—is wonderful. The six-month opiate-free success rate at the clinic is 62 per cent. Put simply, that means that more than 300 drug users who have undergone rapid detoxification using naltrexone have remained off heroin for at least six months. That success rate is in line with other naltrexone clinics around the country. To put it in per spective, the success of methadone treatment is only one or two per cent. Despite the proven success rate and the inspiring stories of personal achievement, the Brisbane clinic still faces a number of problems.

The first problem is that some people in the governments at various levels, and some people in the medical community who have a vested interest in maintaining the status quo, refuse to recognise the value of naltrexone. Although first developed in the United States in 1963, it is only relatively recently that the potential benefits of naltrexone have become more widely known. Naltrexone works by blocking the receptors in the brain. Those receptors help provide users with pleasure from taking various drugs. There have been more than 1,500 studies worldwide that show the effectiveness of naltrexone. It is a proven remedy. The academic war has been won on this it is now time for politicians to act. The first thing the Minister for Health and Aged Care should do is place naltrexone on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. In July this year, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee recommended against the federal government subsidising the cost of naltrexone. I realise that it is impossible for the government to subsidise every single drug that manufacturers bring onto the market. But isn't that why governments have priorities? This government must recognise that heroin is the scourge of the community. It is a drug that wrecks lives and destroys communities.

What this decision has done, however, is take away the hope of thousands and thousands of people trying to get off heroin. On 1 December, the Federal Court will review the PBAC's decision. The government could end a lot of heartache right now by putting naltrexone on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. Last week, the Queensland government showed its commitment to the process of drug rehabilitation by helping work through some problems concerning the prescription of certain other drugs at Dr Reece's clinic. But there are many problems that can be worked on at the federal level to make this program more successful. Dr Reece's clinic treats up to 20 people a week. That represents the chance to get 20 people off heroin. Unfor tunately, the clinic turns away three or four people every week. Those people are turned away for a number of reasons, but one common reason is that they cannot afford the treatment.

The initial cost of treatment is $500. This is the second cheapest privately run naltrexone detoxification program in the country. Five hundred dollars might not sound like much to some, but to drug users it is an awful lot of money. Furthermore, people who have undergone rapid detoxification need to stay on the drug for a year to ensure the treatment works in the long term. Because the treatment is not listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme, patients have to pay $2,000 a year to continue receiving the drug. That means that the people who most need the treatment cannot afford it. The people who would benefit most from the treatment cannot afford it. The clinic could also benefit from increased funding for social workers and a higher number of drug rehabilitation services in Queensland. But understandably, that cannot all be achieved overnight. At the very least, however, the federal government could put naltrexone on the PBS and give people who want to come off heroin the best possible chance.

The other thing the government can do is allow one particular drug buprenorphine to be used in rapid detoxification. Buprenorphine is a drug that is particularly useful in helping treat high-dose methadone and heroin users. Unfortunately, even though the drug can be used for other purposes, regulations prohibit it from being used for the treatment of opiate-addicted people. The alternative to these measures is that we pay for higher levels of crime, higher levels of medical treatment, more overdoses and more deaths. It is a grim alternative indeed.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak this evening on the issue of aquaculture and its potential environmental impact. As senators would probably be aware, yesterday the Senate Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts References Committee tabled a report into the Port Hinchinbrook development. One of the recommendations was to do with assessing the development of aquaculture and its impact on and discharge into the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. That recommendation was provided because the potential environmental impacts of aquaculture, if not done properly, were shown during the course of the inquiry to be a significant potential problem for the environmental health of the Great Barrier Reef and surrounding waters.

speech.para: Aquaculture has been seen in recent years as a potential way forward to feed thousands of hungry people around the world. By the middle of the last decade, the World Bank, the Asian Development Bank and others were putting around $200 million a year into aquaculture projects, and aquaculture has kept growing since that time. The dramatic change now is the final use of the produce of aquaculture: rather than the direct feeding of the hungry, it is often seen as a valuable cash crop, ready for the export markets of poor and wealthy countries alike. It is now a question of who is prepared, under current practice, to enable themselves to get a share of the spoils.

Aquaculture in the United States, for example, has boomed for three different reasons: firstly, a decline in domestic and world fisheries' catches; secondly, an increase in the demand for seafood generally and aquacultural products specifically; and, thirdly, government promotion of aquaculture. Similar reasons are determining the expansion of aquaculture in Australia.

There are some significant issues that I believe need to be addressed and monitored in relation to aquaculture. It is an issue relevant for the country as a whole and certainly relevant for my own state of Queensland. A significant number of prawn farms, in particular, have been established, and many more are proposed. As indicated in the environment committee report into Port Hinchinbrook, there are potential problems—in particular, potential environmental problems—if it is not managed properly.

The aquaculture industry is often promoted as a clean industry but, like any intensive animal industry, it can produce large amounts of polluting waste. Uneaten fish food is a source of nutrients in the form of carbon based organic compounds, nitrogen and phosphorus which can stimulate algae and phytoplankton blooms, cutting out sunlight. When the algae die, they dramatically reduce oxygen levels, which can cause fish and other organisms stress and potentially death. Toxic algae blooms can cause the killing of organisms and the transfer of the toxins through the food chain to humans.

Open nets, used mainly in the farming of salmon and tuna, have the greatest potential to cause environmental damage due to the untreated discharge. Discharges from salmon farms around the coast of British Colombia are estimated to be equivalent to raw human sewage from a city of half a million people. On the other hand, molluscs—such as oysters, clams and muscles—are filter feeders and actually reduce nutrients in marine systems, as 30 to 40 per cent of the total organic matter ingested by the mollusc is used for growth and is permanently removed through harvesting. It is important to note also the potential flow-on effects in terms of other usage of the environment—for example, more than one-quarter of wild fish harvests are now used for animal feed.

The measure of world production of aquaculture when looked at in monetary value rather than weight is fairly different, and the ranking is different for certain products of aquaculture. For example, prawns, while not produced in large weight quantities on a global scale, emerge clearly as a very valuable product. Tiger prawns are ranked 11th in world production by weight but first in value. In Queensland, the varieties that were identified earlier this year as potential stock for aquaculture were prawns, barramundi, pearls, redclaw, ornamental fish, oysters, silver perch, golden perch and crocodiles.

I raise this issue not to try to generate an overall blanket blackening of the name of aquaculture because—as I indicated already this evening—if managed properly and monitored properly, the potential environmental impacts are very much minimised. But the real issue is ensuring that it operates properly, the approvals are done in an efficient and effective way, assessments are done before any approvals are given and ongoing monitoring is effective.

By way of example, a proposed aquaculture farm in North Queensland at Armstrong Beach near Sarina has been a cause of great controversy and concern in that community. That has a Queensland licence to release up to 75,000 cubic metres of waste on any given day, averaging 35,000 cubic metres of waste a day. They will, as part of the development, have permits to clear mangroves, which is fairly ironic, given that mangroves are breeding grounds for wild fisheries. There is very significant community opposition to it in the Sarina area. Yet Armstrong Beach is just one of over 60 sites identified along a 640-kilometre stretch of Central Queensland coast as being potentially suitable for aquaculture. That is one approximately every 10 kilometres.

The federal Minister for the Environment and Heritage, to his credit, has reacted to some of the concerns relating to inappropriate approvals of aquaculture development by proposing regulations for waters that lead into or are part of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park to try to ensure that the potential problems that may occur from aquaculture do not happen and that we do not have those sorts of impacts occurring on the Barrier Reef. It is pleasing to see the federal environment minister working to exercise his responsibilities constructively in that regard. It is one area where I think the environment minister has shown some positive actions in recent years. He has focused on improving the health of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and the world heritage area surrounding it. It is only appropriate, of course, that as federal environment minister he does that to ensure that world heritage values are protected.

The Democrats very much support the aim of the federal environment minister in the regulations that he has put forward. I understand that they are only draft regulations at this stage. It is a source of concern that the Queensland government has come out against what the federal environment minister is trying to do. I believe that the state government's suggestions and the concerns that they have expressed about the likely impact of the proposed regulations are grossly inaccurate and overstated. From my point of view and the Democrats' point of view, it would be far more preferable if the Queensland government took a constructive approach, rather than an alarmist approach, to what the federal environment minister is trying to do.

Clearly, this should not be an issue of arm-wrestling over power and responsibility between state and federal governments; it should be an issue where governments at both levels work together to try to ensure the maximum health of the Barrier Reef. There are many threats to the Barrier Reef—aquaculture is but one—and it is much more important that state and federal governments, both of which have responsibility for managing the Barrier Reef, work together to try to address those potential negative impacts. Certainly it is pleasing to see—and the Democrats are supportive of this—what the federal environment minister is trying to do in relation to ensuring that there are not negative environmental impacts on the Barrier Reef from aquaculture developments.

I am not in any way suggesting that aquaculture is inherently bad or evil. In fact, the aim of the federal environment minister is to, in a way, improve the potential for aquaculture by ensuring that it operates only under best possible practice and that approvals are given only when environmental impact assessments have been done and it has been demonstrated that there will be no negative impacts. Those sorts of circumstances provide the best atmosphere and the best grounding for the ongoing development of that aquaculture industry.

The Democrats are pleased about the concern the federal environment minister has shown about proposals such as that at Armstrong Beach. We urge Senator Hill to continue working in that regard and the Queensland government to take a more constructive approach to ensure that aquaculture developments in Queensland, particularly along the Barrier Reef, operate in a manner that does not damage the reef. We believe that can be done. We encourage all parties to work together to ensure that that is how things are done.

talk.start.para: —Two weeks ago, on 14 September, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority commenced another airspace trial at Yulara in central Australia. The opposition wishes to place on record its serious concerns about the conduct and implications of this trial. I would also like to draw to the Senate's attention the fact that key aspects of the trial run counter to the Senate's disallowance earlier this year of government regulations that would have allowed the contracting out and privatisation of air traffic control services.

speech.para: The opposition has been very firm in its view that air traffic services are a public responsibility—a core responsibility of government, if you like—and should not be run for profit by private operators. The problem we seem to be having in aviation safety in this country is that the coalition government does not see it as a public responsibility. It sees it as just another service—like selling groceries or TV sets or whatever—for which customers must pay and from which every last bit of profit must be wrung irrespective of the wider and longer-term consequences.

There is no doubt that Airservices Australia are less and less interested in providing the full mix of air traffic and information services and more and more interested in restricting their operations to what they see as the potentially high profitable end of the business—that is, en route services. The name of the game appears to be to retain en route services through The Advanced Australian Air Traffic System, TAAATS, and to try to sell TAAATS overseas whilst quietly ditching air traffic and firefighting services at aerodromes and other technical support services.

The opposition does not consider this to be an acceptable and appropriate approach to the management and delivery of air safety and air traffic services in this country. In fact, we see it as a potential recipe for disaster. This new trial at Yulara gives us little cause to become any more relaxed or comfortable about the future of aviation safety under this govern ment. What is happening at Yulara is that CASA is trialling a certified air/ground radio service.

The trial is being funded by Qantas, Ansett and the Ayers Rock resorts. Services have been provided under contract to the resort by a private company called Ambidji. We have several concerns about the trial. Firstly, there appears to have been no tender process and no-one has seen any terms of reference for the trial or anything setting out the outcomes or indicators against which the success of the trial will be measured. That is a major failing of accountability transparency and public scrutiny and one which we believe the minister should immediately redress.

Secondly, the trial effectively privatises these particular air traffic services at this airport during the trial. That cuts directly across the Senate's rejection earlier this year of regulations that would have permitted the contracting out of air traffic services. The Senate very clearly rejected those regulations and it rejected them for very good reasons. It believed that the provision of air traffic and aerodrome safety services was wholly and solely the responsibility of government. It may be that further down the track the government convinces the Senate that some of these sorts of services should be provided by private companies or individuals but, to date, that has not occurred. So to turn around and use a private company to run this trial is, we believe, a direct contravention of the Senate disallowance and a snub to the Senate and the parliament of Australia.

Airservices Australia is clearly charged with the legal responsibility of providing air traffic and aeronautical information services under the Airservices Act. But CASA and Airservices Australia are claiming these particular services, certified air/ground services, are not air traffic services. The argument goes that, if they are not air traffic services, anyone can provide them and Airservices Australia is entitled to decline to become involved. That is patently absurd. Generally, certified air/ground operators provide details of known air traffic and may suggest a course of action to a pilot to assist in the safety of operations. That, in anyone's definition, is an air traffic service. What is happening here, we believe, is that some fancy footwork is being done by CASA and Airservices Australia, with the minister clearly cognisant of this, to get private companies in the door to deliver these services by brazenly denying they are air traffic services.

Thirdly, we have concerns about the role of CASA in this trial. It seems as though CASA asked Airservices Australia to provide the services and they said, `No, we're too busy working out how to make a fortune out of TAAATS.' So CASA, presumably in the interests of wanting to address safety concerns at Yulara, decided to arrange for Ambidji to provide the services for the trial. But that raises a couple of crucial questions: why didn't CASA insist on Airservices Australia coming to the party? What business does CASA have in the arranging or procuring of air traffic services?

I would have thought there were sufficient burnt fingers around, after the disastrous G class airspace trial last year, to at least make them stop and think about a potential conflict of interest with regard to this sort of matter. It seems to me that a more appropriate course of action for CASA to take would have been to go to the minister and say, `Look, we've identified some serious concerns at Yulara. We want to run a trial there to see if we can address those concerns and we want you to tell Airservices Australia, as the organisation responsible for the provision of these services, to cooperate with us in the running of the trial.' We believe that would have been a more appropriate and publicly responsible course of action.

Obviously, my personal view is that there is considerable potential for conflict of interest in having Ansett and Qantas pay for the trial in the first place. I would not have thought there would be many that would demur from that. I think it would have been much more appropriate, from a public policy and public accountability perspective, for CASA and Airservices to share the cost of the trial.

I do understand, of course, the cost pressure that public organisations are under and perhaps everyone jumped at the chance to run a trial with no cost to their budgets. In this day and age, maybe that is understandable in some way. But there are two points to make about that. First, even with airlines funding the trial, Airservices should still have provided the relevant services, not a private company. Secondly, Airservices Australia have just revealed in their corporate plan that they expect to make an operating profit of $228 million over the next five years. Perhaps some of that profit could be directed into assisting the task of making regional aerodromes safer places.

Finally, this trial does not simply reflect poorly on CASA and Airservices Australia; we believe it reflects very badly on the Howard government's agenda for aviation safety in Australia. That agenda—as we saw early this year with the government regulations—is very clearly the privatisation of air traffic control services. You only have to look at Airservices Australia's corporate plan tabled last week to see that agenda expressed very unambiguously. `To achieve its new vision,' the report tells us, `Airservices Australia will position itself to be an aggressive competitor in delivering air traffic management services, aviation rescue and firefighting services and related business, technology and information services in our target markets.' That is what this country's public provider of air traffic services has become: `an aggressive competitor' going after `target markets'.

Are we all going to be happy when we turn around in a few years from now to find that the `aggressive' Airservices Australia is being little more than a marketing agency for the TAAATS system while a foreign owned company—like Serco—runs every other air traffic control service in the country, with perhaps an Australian company picking up a few scraps here and there? I do not think so. Are we seriously expected to believe that will be an improvement on having a publicly owned and controlled Airservices Australia providing air traffic services across the board? Obviously, we do not think that will be an improvement.

If he learned nothing more from the Victorian state election, I would have thought Minister Anderson might have realised that Australians living in regional areas are sick and tired of—and have rejected—an agenda that places privatisation and the pursuit of competition ahead of every other value. I would have thought he might have started to realise that a great many Australians think there are other values worth placing ahead of competition at any cost.

Labor believes that one of those axiomatic values is that aviation safety is a public responsibility and that air traffic services should be provided by government and motivated by the need for the protection of public safety—not by the need to make a profit. That is why we will continue to oppose the privatisation of air traffic and airport firefighting services. We will continue to point out to the minister that setting Airservices Australia on this new path of aggressive competition in target markets while failing to meet its current obligations is an approach in direct contradiction to what we believe is the government's responsibility to provide a safe aviation environment.

(4) (a) Yes. Attached is a copy of the speech delivered at the launch of the exhibition in Canberra on 9 November 1999 by Barry Cusack, Managing Director of Rio Tinto Australia. All subsequent speeches by Rio Tinto representatives delivered similar messages.

(b) No. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade received an advance copy of the speech by the Managing Director of Rio Tinto Australia at the launch of the exhibition in Canberra. Speeches by Rio Tinto representatives at openings at other venues were similar in content.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 24 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that : (a) Acrolein, a chemical used to control weeds in irrigation channels, is often mixed with hydroquinone to keep Acrolein stable; (b) hydroquinone is carcinogenic and a germ-cell mutagen; (c) the carcinogenic properties of acrolein have not been fully evaluated due to the chemical's extreme acute toxicity, that is, laboratory animals die before carcinogenic effects have can be identified; (d) some operators who have been involved in injecting acrolein into water supplies cannot read well and would have difficulty completing formal training courses in the safe use of the chemical; (e) acrolein is listed as a possible carcinogen in the Hazardous Substances Resources Guide and that other effects of exposure include nausea, headaches, pulmonary oedema and possible death; and (f) extreme effects of prolonged exposure to acrolein on skin and eyes, or, if swallowed; if so, why did the Minister not refer to these effects in his answer to question on notice No. 396 (Senate Hansard , 8 August 1999, p. 2443).

(2) Is the Minister aware that: (a) some of the highest concentrations of acrolein have been measured in irrigation canals, particularly in the United States of America; (b) workers have inhaled excessive quantities of acrolein vapour in New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria; and (c) vapour from an injection into the Yarrawonga main canal in Victoria caused discomfort to residents in nearby houses.

(3) Is the Minister also aware: (a) of the case of Mr Ian Deacon, who was not notified of an injection of acrolein into the canal near his farm in 1993; (b) that Mr Deacon and his family were poisoned by acrolein; and (c) that Mr Deacon's battery-hen business was destroyed by acrolein poisoning.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Yes.
(b) The Department of Health and Aged Care advises that long-term (2 years) feeding studies in mice and rats indicate that hydroquinone has a marginal carcinogenic potential.

(c) The Department of Health and Aged Care advises that it assessed the carcinogenic potential of acrolein in 1994 using the full range of studies normally used to assess the carcinogenic potential of agricultural chemicals. Each of the studies produces a clear `No Observed Effect Level', and there was no evidence of any significant increase in cancer incidence seen at any dose in any of these studies.

(d) Under the National Registration Scheme for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals, control-of-use remains a State/Territory function. Those States in which acrolein is registered for use (New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria and Western Austral ia) advise that they are unaware of operators of acrolein equipment in their jurisdictions who cannot read well. Any evidence to the contrary should be supplied to relevant State officials, who will investigate the matter.

(e) The Department of Health and Aged Care advises that it is not aware of the Hazardous Substances Resources Guide. A recognised international reference is published by the International Agency for Research on Cancer. It shows acrolein as being in Group 3; ie it is not classifiable as to its carcinogenicity to humans. This listing is due to the inadequacy of the data reviewed to make a clear determination of the carcinogenic potential, rather than to indications that acrolein is likely to cause cancer. The current Acceptable Daily Intake for acrolein is 0.0005 milligram per kilogram of bodyweight per day. Accordingly, a daily oral intake of 0.035 mg per day for a 70 kg person should not present an appreciable health risk.

(f) The Department of Health and Aged Care advises that acrolein has an odour perception threshold of around 0.07 mg per cubic metre, which should assist in avoiding hazardous levels in air. Accordingly, prolonged exposure or swallowing is extremely improbable.
In view of the foregoing, it is apparent that the answer to question on notice No. 396 was complete and accurate.
(2) (a) As acrolein is registered for use in canals it is to be expected that elevated concentrations of acrolein are to be found there, rather than elsewhere.
(b) Officials from New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria advise that they are unaware of any basis for this allegation. Any evidence should be supplied to relevant State officials.

(c) Goulburn Murray Water advises that an incident in Yarrawonga occurred approximately 20 years ago, which is prior to the introduction of the present controls over use. At that time, acrolein was used at concentrations of 30 to 50 parts per million, whereas the concentration used now is 0.5 parts per million.

(3) (a), (b) and (c) This issue has not been brought to the Federal Government's attention. However, it is a State issue. State Governments advise they are unaware of the alleged incident. Any evidence on this matter should be supplied to relevant State officials.
