subdebateinfo.title: Papua New Guinea: Western Province Coastal Zone Management Project
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1420)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID) currently considering implementing the Western Province Coastal Zone Management Project in Papua New Guinea (PNG).
(2) Is the project in the catchment area of the Fly River, the same catchment area which has suffered massive environmental damage as a result of the Ok Tedi mine in which BHP is a major shareholder.

(3) Is it a fact that, until recently, AusAID: (a) regarded the project as poorly conceived and that is likely to cause more problems that it will solve; and (b) considered it unlikely to receive financial support.
(4) Is the project currently being `fast-tracked' by AusAID.
(5) Is AusAID's sudden endorsement of the project a response to BHP's rumoured withdrawal from Ok Tedi Mining Limited (OTML).
(6) What is the Minister's position with respect to BHP's legal obligations to compensate landowners and rehabilitate the environment affected by the Ok Tedi mine.
(7) Is it the intention of AusAID to provide support for those communities in the Ok Tedi area that have been affected by the operations of the BHP subsidiary, OTML.

(8) Is the Minister aware of any plans by BHP to sell its shares of OTML to a Chinese or Dutch mining company and thereby pass on its responsibilities to those affected by the mine's environmental damage to the PNG Government and a third party.
(9) Has the Minister, his department or AusAID had any meetings with BHP at which the issues of the project or BHP's withdrawal from Ok Tedi mine were discussed.
(10) Is the Minister aware that OTML recently admitted that the environmental impacts of the Ok Tedi mine `would be far greater and more damaging than predicted.
(11) Does the Minister have a view on whether Australian taxpayers' money should be channelled through AusAID to rehabilitation works that are rightfully the legal responsibility of BHP.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (1) AusAID officials are currently considering a project design document for a coastal zone management project in Western Province of PNG.

(2) The proposed project is not in the Fly River watershed area but does include part of the Fly River delta. The project has been designed to be contiguous with but not including communities which previously received compensation from OTML. Planned activities in the WPCZM Project are located over 250 km from the Ok Tedi mine.

(3) No. The project's objectives are sound. The project is planned in a difficult environment. For this reason AusAID has moved forward cautiously and sought to improve the design to maximise sustainability. Approval for the project will not be given until Mr Downer is satisfied with the project design.

(4) The proposed project is not being `fast-tracked'. The project has not yet been approved. Consideration of the redesigned project is nearing completion in line with quality assurance processes built into the project development cycle.
(5) AusAID's consideration of the project design document is part of the normal project cycle and unrelated to Ok Tedi mining operations.
(6) The legal obligations of OTML are a matter for the Board and shareholders of OTML.
(7) AusAID has no intention of providing support for communities affected by the operations of OTML.
(8) No. BHP has indicated that it will consider its future involvement pending a decision by OTML on the future of the mine.

(9) Yes. AusAID and DFAT officials have attended briefing sessions provided by BHP on the future of Ok Tedi mine. The issue has also been discussed at Australia-PNG Business Council (APNGBC) meetings (at which AusAID and DFAT officials were present).
(10) Yes. OTML released an environmental impact options report in August indicating that the environmental effects of the mine would be far greater and more damaging than predicted.

(11) OTML has advised DFAT officials that the clean-up of the Fly River system and rehabilitation of local communities will be considered in the OTML closure plan. There is no intention to use aid funding to rehabilitate environmental damage caused by the OK Tedi mine.
